title: Susan B. Anthony Papers: Daybook and Diaries, 1856-1906; Diaries; 1874

entries.fullText:
There will be four Eclipses this year, and a transit of Venus:
I. A Total Eclipse of the Sun, April 16, invisible.
II. A Partial Eclipse of the Moon, May 1, invisible.
III. An Annular Eclipse of the Sun, Oct. 10, invisible.
IV. A Total Eclipse of the Moon, in the evening of Oct. 24th, and morning of the 25th, visible throughout America. Begins at New York, Oct. 25th, 0h. 45m. morning. Total at 2h. 4m. Middle at 2h. 20 1/2m. Total ends at 2h. 37m. End of Eclipse at 3h. 55 1/2m.
V. A transit of Venus, Dec. 8th, invisible in America. Visible in Asia, Australia, and part of Africa and Europe.

entries.fullText:
DOMESTIC POSTAGE.

On all LETTERS throughout the United States, 3 cts.
for each half ounce or fraction thereof.
Drop of LOCAL LETTERS, 2 cts. per half ounce
where there is a free carrier's delivery; other offices,
1 ct.
POSTAL CARDS, 1 ct.
VALUABLE LETTERS may be registered by the payments
of a registration fee of 5 cts. MONEY can be sent with absolute safety by mail by procuring a
Money Order. The fees are, on orders not exceeding $10, 5 cts. ; $10 to $20, 10 cts. ; $20 to $30, 15 cts. ;
$30 to $40, 20 cts. ; $40 to $50, 25 cts.
PRINTED BOOKS, in one packages, to one address 2
c ts. for each 2 ounces of fraction thereof, not over 4 lbs.
ON TRANSIENT NEWSPAPERS, or PRINTED MATTER
(Books excepted), and on Circulars, Pamphlets,
Book Manuscripts and Proof sheets, Maps, Sheet
Music, Chromos, Engravings and Photographs, 1
c t. for each 2 ounces or fraction thereof, not over 4 lbs.
Samples of Mdse. (except liquids), Ores &c., Flexible
Patterns, Paper, Envelopes, Blanks, 2 cts. for
each 2 ounces, not over 12 ounces.
All Transient Matter, except duly certified letters
of Soldiers and Sailors, must be prepaid by stamps.
On matter not above specified, same rates as letters.
entries.summaryText: Details of domestic postage rates and regulations.

entries.fullText:
FOREIGN POSTAGE.

ON LETTERS TO GREAT BRITAIN AND IRELAND--For
every half ounce of fraction thereof, 6 cts. if prepaid.
If not prepaid, 6 cts. extra will be collected in Great
Britain, and 6 cts. in the United States.
TO THE GERMAN STATES--For every half ounce or
fraction thereof, via N. German Union direct, 6 cts. ;
closed mail via England, 7 cts., prepayment optional.
TO FRANCE (payment compulsory), 10 cts. for each
jalf ounce of fraction thereof, direct mail ' 4 cts.
(open mail) by England. Fully prepaid via England
one third ounce, 10 cts. ; one third to one half
ounce, cts. ' once half to two thirds ounce, 20 cts ;
TO THE DOMINION OF CANADA, NOVA SCOTIA, NEWFOUNDLAND,
&c., per half ounce, any distance, 6 cts.,
if prepaid ' if not paid, 10 cts
entries.summaryText: Details of foreign postage rates and regulations.

entries.fullText:
At South Branch,
N. Jersey - My old friend,
Mary Ann McLean's
home - and Rev. Wm.
Pitcher - His son
Charles & daughter Jenny at
Home - Cloudy, Foggy
day - Roast turkey
for dinner - A telegram
from Mrs. L. D. Blake
to South Branch - gave
me great scare, fear
lest mother was ill
one gone over the river.
- A boy brought it over
4 miles and charged
$2. Had a good
and long talk with
Mary then - Mr. Domino
as she calls Mr. P. was
in his study all day - & had one
of his head aches - took ride
in afternoon
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends New Year's Day at her friend Mary Ann McLean's home in South Branch, N. Jersey. She receives a telegram from Mrs. L. D. Blake that scares her, but it turns out to be a false alarm. She has a good talk with Mary and Mr. Domino, who has a headache.

entries.fullText:
At South Branch NY
In P.M. visited
Public School with
Mr Pitcher & Mary Ann -
Mr. Pitcher addressed
the school - Then I
told them the old talk
of school visitors to boys
& girls
entries.summaryText: Visited a public school in South Branch NY with Mr. Pitcher and Mary Ann and spoke to the students.

entries.fullText:
Left S. Branch at
9.20 for Somerville
Charlie & Jenny drove
me over with Old Don
that sister Gula rode
after so many times
when here last May,
June - very foggy crossing;
the ferry - called on
Mrs Phelps - Went to
Tenafly - Fog very dense-
the last boat was delayed
three hours - so had to
wait in Jersey Depot -
Found Mrs Stanton well
& Bob cheerful & bright -
but he must [?]
vitality, lying in bed
all those weeks
entries.summaryText: Traveled from South Branch to Somerville and then to Tenafly, encountering dense fog and delays. Visited Mrs. Phelps and found Mrs. Stanton and Bob doing well, but Bob was still recovering from weeks in bed.

entries.fullText: At Tenafly. Theodore left Saturday A.M. for Cornell - Maggie & Hattie still at home --
entries.summaryText: Theodore left for Cornell while Maggie and Hattie stayed home in Tenafly.

entries.fullText: At Tenafly.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was in Tenafly.

entries.fullText: At Tenafly

entries.summaryText: Short entry stating that Susan B. Anthony was in Tenafly on January 7, 1874.

entries.fullText: At Tenafly
entries.summaryText: Short journal entry stating that Susan B. Anthony was in Tenafly on January 9, 1874.

entries.fullText:
Left Tenafly
at 5pm - took
street car down to
Cortland depot - 5[?]
sleeping car for
Washington
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left Tenafly and took a street car to Cortland depot to catch a sleeping car for Washington.

entries.fullText:
Arrived Washington
at 6 a.m. Went to
Emma Griffings to
breakfast then called
on Mrs. E Ca- & then
at Senator Sargent's -
308 F- St. and they
all insisted I should
stop with them - so
at even'g went round
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived in Washington and had breakfast at Emma Griffings' before visiting Mrs. E Ca- and Senator Sargent. They insisted she stay with them, so she did.

entries.fullText:
At Washington
at A.A. Sargent's
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was in Washington at A.A. Sargent's on January 12, 1874.

entries.fullText: At Washington
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was in Washington on January 13, 1874.

entries.fullText: At Washington
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote a brief entry on January 14, 1874, stating that she was in Washington.

entries.fullText: National W. P. Convention at Lincoln Hall. Opened with fine audience but cold hall
entries.summaryText: On January 15, 1874, Susan B. Anthony attended the National W. P. Convention at Lincoln Hall in Washington D.C. She noted that the audience was fine but the hall was cold.

entries.fullText:
6th National W. S. Convention
in Washington D.C.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attended the 6th National Women's Suffrage Convention in Washington D.C.

entries.fullText: at Washington
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was in Washington.

entries.fullText:
At Mrs Sargents - Washington -
B.F. Butler presented petition
600 - names for suffrage in D.C.
Dawes of Mass. offered bill for
W.S. in the District -
President Grant sent in name
of Morris R. Wait of Toledo O.
for Chief Justice - good -
Put my petition in hands of
Wm. A. Boughridge of Iowa -
this was done the 19th
This P.M. Mr & Mrs. S. &
self rode all over Washington
my first ride over the city
though I have been here every
winter the past - 6 years
Phebe Couzens & I called on
Mrs Barnard -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony presents a petition for suffrage in D.C. and puts her petition in the hands of Wm. A. Boughridge of Iowa. She rides all over Washington and calls on Mrs. Barnard.

entries.fullText:
Mrs. H. M. Barnard
will look after my
petition in both
Houses-
entries.summaryText: Mrs. H. M. Barnard will look after Susan B. Anthony's petition in both houses.

people: B. A. Lockwood - F. E. Burr
entries.fullText: - Hearing before the House Judiciary Committee - F. Miller, S.J. Spencer, B. A. Lockwood - F. E. Burr, P.W. Couzens, & self - all crowded into 45 minutes - Found letters at house - so, took the 9 P.M. train for New York -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends a hearing before the House Judiciary Committee in Washington D.C. and then takes a train to New York.

entries.fullText: Reached New York at 7 A.M. and breakfasted with Mrs Murray - then had a short call with Mrs Phelps - & took cars for Albany at 10.20 - found Mrs Blake on board - I went direct to Phebe Jones & dined & then to Lydia Mott's - she is better but very feeble & bad cough -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from New York to Albany and visits with various acquaintances, including Phebe Jones and Lydia Mott.

entries.fullText:
Hearing before the
Assembly Judiciary Committee
Prince Chaim(?)
Had assembly chamber
packed - Mrs Blake
spoke first - then I - &
lastly Mrs Gage - all
chimed in together well
Was dreadfully cut down
this A.M. - by letter to my
sister Mary with Stillmans to
her - threatening to sue the
four givers of the note - if
the whole $1000 - was not
paid by Feb. 1st - and I
had to [?][?] in writing
Begged Stillman to accept the $100 - I
could now pay him & wait my
possibilities - & Mrs Stanton to go
to N. J - & loan it pay it & trust me.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends a hearing before the Assembly Judiciary Committee in Albany, NY. She receives a threatening letter regarding a note and asks Stillmans to accept $100 and wait for the rest. She also asks Mrs. Stanton to go to N.J. to loan and pay the rest.

entries.fullText:
From Albany at 2.35
Springfield- Mass- 7.30
Staid all night
at Springfield-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Albany to Springfield and stays overnight.

entries.fullText:
stopped at Ward Cheeneys-
Six brothers- & nephews &
nieces husbands - all engaged
in manufacturing silk - names
M. John, Charles, Ward,
Frank & wife Susan, Ralph -
each of the brothers lives
in a beautiful cottage
Wards wife been dead nine years
entries.summaryText: Visited Ward Cheeneys and met six brothers, nephews, and nieces who are all engaged in manufacturing silk.

entries.fullText:
Mrs Hooker preached
in Cherry Hall at 11 A.M.
on forgiving the sinner - but not
the sin -
entries.summaryText: Attended a sermon by Mrs Hooker at Cherry Hall on the topic of forgiving the sinner but not the sin.

entries.fullText:
Mr. Ward took me all through
the silk mills - the perfection
of the marking is wonderful
Left South Manchester at 11/2 P.M.- made
two hours at Vernon depot-& reached
Rockville at 4 P.M.
Stopped at Hotel-
Had a good audience-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits silk mills in Rockville Ct and has a good audience.

entries.fullText:
Spiritualists Hall -
packed house & many left for
want of room -
got letters here,
from J.W. Stillman on the
$1000. Note - he is bound
to sue the givers of it-
& Mrs Stanton writes my
sister Mary that my
family ought to pay it-
& they don't see with
her - they got none of the
good from the Revolution &
Mrs Stanton got a great
deal -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends a packed event at Spiritualists Hall in Willimantic and receives letters regarding a $1000 note and her family's responsibility to pay it.

entries.fullText:
Mr. E.C. Stone
stopped with Sarah
M. Kingsley -
Mrs E.R. Davis
Mrs Hine - Jeweller
of Webster, Mass
entries.summaryText: Mr. E.C. Stone stopped with Sarah M. Kingsley and met with Mrs E.R. Davis and Mrs Hine, a jeweller from Webster, Mass.

entries.fullText:
Mr. J. Q. A. Stone
No meeting here -
spent this night with
Mrs Lita. Barney Sayles
of Dayville - had a
nice rest -
entries.summaryText: Mr. J. Q. A. Stone spent the night with Mrs Lita. Barney Sayles of Dayville and had a nice rest, but there was no meeting in Danielsville Ct.

entries.fullText: Stopped with Mrs A.H. Hakes - who keeps a boarding school -- Had splendid free Audience - 1000 - or more - Sent $200. P.O. orders to Mrs Phelps - New York - & telegraphed J.W. Stillman to call on her & get it - and wrote her to try & stop him from suing Mrs Stanton, A.E. Dickins & P.W. Davis -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony stayed with Mrs. A.H. Hakes in Norwich, CT and had a successful audience of 1000 or more. She sent $200 in P.O. orders to Mrs. Phelps in New York and telegraphed J.W. Stillman to get it. She also wrote to Mrs. Phelps to try and stop him from suing Mrs. Stanton, A.E. Dickins, and P.W. Davis.

entries.fullText: Hon Thomas M. Waller Lawrence Hall- & Crocker Hotel - Mr & Mrs D.B. Chapman - Pretty good audience
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was in New London and had a pretty good audience. She stayed at Lawrence Hall and Crocker Hotel and met with Hon Thomas M. Waller and Mr. & Mrs. D.B. Chapman.

entries.fullText: spent this day at Crocker’s Hotel–worked all day copying & cutting down argument & trial–
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spent the day at Crocker’s Hotel in New London copying and cutting down argument and trial.

entries.fullText: O.A. Coleman Student of Wesleyan University - Has four young women students—one a niece of Lucy Stone’s—Mrs. Phebe R. Clark. Mrs. W. W. Wilcox & Mrs. N. C. Stiles—good women—[?] Got letter from sister Mary; Mother had a setback last Tuesday—& sister Hannah’s sore—or blister on right little finger. That Dr. Moore says is a bad thing. It does seem as if the evil fates had set in against us, as a family—always so strong & healthful—but it seems now said, sad–Eleven years ago [?] 9 [?] - 3 [?] [?] Gula
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony met with O.A. Coleman, a student at Wesleyan University, and received a letter from her sister Mary about their mother's setback and sister Hannah's sore finger. She reflects on the health of her family and mentions a past event from eleven years ago.

entries.fullText:
at Universalist Church -0
Secretaryk-State Charities of
Connecticut
at her brother's H. C. Zale
Pastor Universalist Church &
Prof. Natural science at
Canton University N. Z.
entries.summaryText: Meeting at Universalist Church with various people including Hon. J. H. Lewis and Rev. J. H. Chapin, and visits to other locations.

entries.fullText:
Norwalk Ct-. 
Ms Sara M. S. Huntington
entries.summaryText: Journal entry dated February 5, 1874, written in Norwalk Ct-. Mentions Ms Sara M. S. Huntington.

A. H. Terry - Southold
Suffolk Co. - N.Y. - mainly

J.M. Bailey Editor
The Danbury News

Danbury, Ct.
J.M. Bailey Editor
The Danbury News
A. H. Terry - Southold
Suffolk Co. - N.Y. - mainly

entries.summaryText: Journal entry dated February 6, 1874, written in Danbury, Ct. Mentions J.M. Bailey Editor, The Danbury News, A. H. Terry, and Suffolk Co. - N.Y. - mainly. Also mentions tracts & documents -.

entries.fullText: meeting in Old Doctor Beechers Church - now [thrown?] up & a new church built - Flora Gould Vail - Julia M. Vail -
entries.summaryText: Meeting in Old Doctor Beechers Church in Litchfield with George A. Hickox, Flora Gould Vail, and Julia M. Vail.

entries.fullText: at Mr Geo A Hickox - Mrs Mary Brisbane Hickox Miss Nina H. Brisbane
entries.summaryText: At Mr. Geo A Hickox's house in Litchfield with Mrs. Mary Brisbane Hickox and Miss Nina H. Brisbane.

entries.fullText:
L. Wetmore Esq.
meeting in Town Hall -
Lauren Wetmore is
our old anti slavery
friend of N.Y. City - & a
most hearty welcome we
did have at his house -
Letter from Mary & Sara
reporting to Saturday A.M.
Mother no worse
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends a meeting in Town Hall in Wolcottville with Lauren Wetmore, an old anti-slavery friend from N.Y. City. She receives a letter from Mary and Sara reporting that Mother is no worse.

entries.fullText:
Ed. Herald J. H. Vail –
Son of old lady Flora
Vail of Litchfield
Wm. L. Camp – young
man I met on Des Moisnes
R.R. three years ago – married
now – a beautiful young woman
of Des Moisnes and has girl baby –
L. C. Pinney Ed. Winston Press –
met Rose Terry Cooke
here – don't believe in Suffrage
writes poetry – but was shocked
at Mrs. Hooker's talk of Socialists
– Had fine audience
and Mr. Camp's uncle gave
use of it free of charge
Letter from sister Mary
to Sunday noon – Mother
seemed gaining very little – but
it is clearly her last sickness
& it does take all of my
courage & philosophy to stay
here to fill this week's meetings
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends a meeting in Winsted, Ct and meets several people including Ed. Herald J. H. Vail, Wm. L. Camp, L. C. Pinney, and Rose Terry Cooke. She receives a letter from sister Mary reporting that Mother is not doing well and it is clearly her last sickness.

entries.fullText:
Telegram here dated 11th – startled
me – but it said – Mother
better – Mary says fill engagements
to 15th - then come - also a
letter dated Monday the 9th –
which said better come
home at once – Mother
asking for me very
often –
entries.summaryText: Received a telegram and letter from Mary about Mother's health.

entries.fullText:
Had a splendid
audience and a good
meeting – Mrs Perkins
spoke a few words –
Found no letter
here – So suppose
Mother is no worse -
entries.summaryText: Attended a good meeting in Bridgeport and received no news about Mother's health.

entries.fullText:
at Allyn Hall –
Left Bridgeport at 10 A.M.
– Had telegram at Hartford
– Mother no worse – So
I can go through to night
and then two days more and
then home Monday –
Tarried all day – Hall
had fully 600 people and a
good meeting –
It has been a most
successful campaign of
meetings –
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is in Hartford, Connecticut and receives a telegram that her mother is no worse. She attends a meeting at Allyn Hall and plans to return home on Monday.

entries.fullText:
Town Hall – in which
the Misses Smith protested
against taxation without
representation –
Howard Hale took
Ellen Burr and self out to G.
8 miles in open two horse
waggon – and a pleasant ride
– [?] at the Misses Smith's
Gate and Julia and Abby came tripping
down to the waggon like girls of
16 though they are said to be 82
and 75
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends a meeting at the Town Hall in Glastonbury, Connecticut where the Misses Smith protest against taxation without representation. She also goes on a pleasant ride with Howard Hale and Ellen Burr to visit the Misses Smith, who are surprisingly spry for their age.

entries.fullText:
My 54th Birth Day

Mr Dill came to
Mrs Smiths - talked until
2 P.M. with the Sisters-
then rode to Hartford with
Mr Dill - & found Mrs Hooker
at Mr Burrs- Mr. Dill was
invited in - & presently came
Ellen Burr & Howard Hale &
sister from Glastonbury -
- and jolly dinner hour
we had from 4 1/2 to 5 1/2 -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her 54th birthday celebration with Mr. Dill, Mrs. Hooker, Mr. Burrs, Ellen Burr, Howard Hale, and a sister from Glastonbury in Hartford.

entries.fullText:
Left Hartfort Ct -
Mr Alfred E. Burrs at
9.40 A.M - - Left Ellen E. Burr
very ill- like
sister Mary - Mrs
Burr gave me nice
Lunch - reached [?]
at 11 P.M. - found
Mother awake & ready
& watching - said she
had asked out to live
until I should get home
omit ? she is better - all day -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony leaves Hartford and visits Mr. Alfred E. Burrs and Ellen E. Burr, who is very ill, before returning home to find her mother awake and waiting for her.

entries.fullText:
Mother seems very
bright this A.M. - &
glad & restful that I
am at home -
sister Mary sick
enough - has not had
so severe a time for
two years-
Sister Hannah
came in & I ran
down to niece Maggies
just an hour- Harry
looks slim enough- has
had lung fever- & little
Jonny too- & Maggie
has had cold & seems
tired & worried out
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her family's health and her visit to her niece Maggie.

entries.fullText:
Mother more
comfortable - Mary
better - she got mother
up on chair - to have
bed made - she was
some faint-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her mother and sister Mary's health.

entries.fullText:
At Home - Mother
a little better -
Letter from Carter &
Thompson - Anna E. Dickins
son's lawyers- asking what
I proposed to do about the
Stillman note - showing that
she would not loan a
dollar to me to save
their ? suit - Any [?]
than Mrs. Davis or Mrs.
Stanton - not one of
them felt the slightest
responsibility to aid me -)
Sister Mary went into
school to day - & left
mother in my charge
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony receives a letter from Carter and Thompson, Anna E. Dickinson's lawyers, regarding the Stillman note. She notes that no one, including Mrs. Davis or Mrs. Stanton, felt any responsibility to aid her. Sister Mary went to school and left mother in her charge.

entries.fullText:
At Home - Mother
a little more comfortable-
Letter from Sister Annie-
all well there -
Went down town
before dinner - bought
more blankets - a rubber
water bottle for Mother
- went to lunch - found
Huldah Anthony here - & so
went to niece Maggie's
- Harry better - but looks
funny & is weak -
Got off letter to
J.W. Stillman - with
check of $600 - principal
$11- interest & 18 Costs of
suit to collect- Loaned
$500- of sister Mary to
put it up- now all my
debts are to Mother & Mary.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony goes to town to buy more supplies for her mother and meets with Huldah Anthony. She also visits her niece Maggie and finds Harry looking weak. She sends a letter to J.W. Stillman with a check of $600 and loans $500 from Sister Mary to put it up. All her debts are now to Mother and Mary.

entries.fullText:
At home - Mother sat
on chair 5 minutes while bed
was made - but very tired -
Card from Elihu W. Anthony
that is Father - Uncle Elihu
Anthonys youngest son - died
Tuesday the 17th at Benj. M.
Anthonys at Detroit, Mich and
buried at Union springs the 20th
Went down town to
Pinity office about report-
Saw Judge Selden-
he spent yeaterday & day beofre writing
out his argument in my case
Mary Hallowell, Mrs
L.C. Smith called on
[?] P.M.- never
thought to tell them to
move to get women
nominated as members
of board of education. - it
is time for Rochester to move
entries.summaryText: Received a card from Elihu W. Anthony about the death of his youngest son, went to the Pinity office to discuss a report and saw Judge Selden, and had visitors Mary Hallowell and Mrs. L.C. Smith.

entries.fullText:
At home
Rainy & very icy-
Mother seems more
comfortable- but does
not gain strength-
Aaron dined at Maggies
Harry better-
entries.summaryText: Stayed at home, rainy and icy weather, mother not gaining strength, Aaron dined at Maggie's, Harry is doing better.

entries.fullText:
May had no school -
National Holiday-
Letter from Mrs. Hooker -
she is well satisfied with
the Ct. work of ours -
and wants me to go back -
- but cannot until Mother
is better - Dr. Moore here
this P.M. Says he thinks
now she will get up
very soon - the
swelling broke to day - &
discharged immensely -
& generally she seems to be
[?] - but says she
is so weak she must
grunt every breath.
entries.summaryText: Received a letter from Mrs. Hooker who is satisfied with the work in Ct. and wants me to go back, but I cannot until Mother is better. Dr. Moore visited and thinks she will recover soon.

entries.fullText:
Beverly W. Jones arrested this A.M. &
taken to jail - His
father paid his fine
& he was soon [?]
Marsh arrested in
P.M.- and I called
at Jail about 6 P.M.
Then walked through
snow to Judge Selden's
he was gone- then
walked to Democrat
office- & home at 10-
couldn't bear to leave
Marsh in that dolorous
place over night-
entries.summaryText: Beverly W. Jones and Marsh were arrested and taken to jail. Susan B. Anthony visited Marsh in jail and walked through the snow to Judge Selden's and the Democrat office before returning home.

entries.fullText:
Saw Judge
Selden-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony saw Judge Selden.

entries.fullText: Left home at 2 p.m. - saw Van Vhooris - he says the Inspectors can be gotten out of jail on the limits and he will get them out - arrived at Weedsport- 5 P.M. Willard Hotel- very small audience- only $5.50 taken - Lawyer Little would not allow me to pay balance of hall rent- $4.50 Took Carriage at 11 for Port Byron- Rochester at 3.15 - Policemen Burns took me to Corners, then [?] {contine along bottom of next page} & another, till I reached home
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to Weedsport and Port Byron, meets Van Vhooris, Lawyer Little, and Policemen Burns, and is unable to pay the balance of hall rent.

entries.fullText: Rochester to Dansville Self - no at 9.10 - meet Dr. J.C Jackson & Son James on Cars- Had fine audience in our home chapel- Liberty Hill- and made pretty good speech- Hite of very weariness & sleepyness
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to Dansville, meets Dr. J.C Jackson and Son James, and gives a speech at Liberty Hill despite feeling very tired.

entries.fullText:
At Dansville
Our home - room 7 -
Had good sleep -
Breakfast at Bright Side
Dr. Jackson's family residence
Elise Durleigh, Rev Mr
Woodruff of Brooklyn - &
Mr & Mrs Brooks of
of Chicago - Heard
the Paster lecture on
neither male nor female
in Christ Jesus - John [?]
to 8 - had reception at
Bright Side - pleasant
chat - a nice purse
of $61.75 presented me -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is in Dansville and attends a lecture on gender and religion.

entries.fullText:
Left Dansville at
7 A.M. for Rochester -
went direct to jail -
took a 9.30 breakfast in
the Inspectors cell - Mrs
Truesdell had sent basket of
lunch & pail of coffee - Hall
& Marsh put up good
cheer - but Marsh's business
is suffering & his wife is
threatening to pay the fine -
Then to Van Vhooris office
& to Marshall Reeves to get
boys out on limits - sent
telegram to Crowley -
[Revue?] at 1 - Telegram
from Senator A. A. Sargent
saying President was
making out papers to
release the Inspectors -
Inspectors bailed out on
the limits at 6 P.M.
Uncle Humphrey Anthony &
Son Willie came at night -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits the jail in Rochester and receives a basket of lunch and coffee from Mrs. Truesdell.

entries.fullText:
City Election- Marsh L. Jones re-elected
to the office of Inspector by a good majority vote - thus
has the 8th ward rebuked
Judge Hunt by honoring
the boys. The day was
perfectly beautiful -
I did not attempt to
vote. as Sylvester Lever's
scratched my name off
the register, list last fall -
Beutiful spring day-
Eugene took
Humphrey about to
Mrs C S-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about the City Election in the 8th ward and her inability to vote due to her name being scratched off the register.

entries.fullText:
At Home
lovely day again-
Uncle humphrey left
on 10A.M. train-
Eugene went with him
E. begins work again
after a vacation since last
October-
Mother enjoyed
Uncle Humphreys
visit very much-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about Uncle Humphrey leaving and Eugene returning to work after a vacation, and her mother enjoying Uncle Humphrey's visit.

entries.fullText:
Mother going
by slowly
entries.summaryText: Mother is going slowly.

entries.fullText: Mother improving
entries.summaryText: Mother is improving.

entries.fullText:
Mother gaining
strength every day
still sits up but a
few minutes at a time.
In P.M. Went down
town - had a long
talk with Judge Selden
the pamphlet printing
goes very slowly -
entries.summaryText: Susan talks about her mother's health, her visit to Judge Selden and the slow progress of pamphlet printing.

entries.fullText:
In P.M. called
at W. R. Hallowells
found him ill - not
been out since election
day - Amy Post
ill to day, too -
Five weeks to day
since mother's attack
entries.summaryText: Susan talks about her visit to W. R. Hallowell and finding him ill, Amy Post being ill, and the five weeks since her mother's attack.

entries.fullText:
Woman suffrage reception
in honor the Inspectors
of the 8th Ward at Sister
Hannahs - It was the most terrible snow
storm & blow of the winter
Still near 50 came and
we had a delightful time.
Hall, the Democratic Inspector
did not come,
Mother sat up about
an hour to day - but is
sleepy & tired most the
time -
3 weeks to night
since I reached
home from Connectiuct
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends a woman suffrage reception in honor of the Inspectors of the 8th Ward at Sister Hannahs despite a terrible snowstorm and Hall, the Democratic Inspector, not showing up. Her mother is tired and sleepy most of the time.

entries.fullText:
At Home - snowy &
blowy - washed Mother &
worked over until 11 - then
Maria Anthony staid with her
& I ran down to printers -
Letter from Cousin E.P. Caldwell
all well there - Mrs. Stanton sends
a card - her Bob dressed & down
stairs Sunday for the first in four
months - 11 Letter from B.F.
Butler - good word about
Inspectors & my petition -
Kansas Legislation - Assembly
lostt woman suffrage bill by
two notes 58 to 32 - too bad -
I did hope we could try our
luck in Kansas again this year.
D. Reid paper reports him as
having to pay $2,500 - as [?]
on note for friend -
If so to rather a generous dose -
That friend was Thad- Walker. //
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony receives a letter from Cousin E.P. Caldwell and Mrs. Stanton, and a good word from B.F. Butler about Inspectors and her petition. She is disappointed to hear that the woman suffrage bill was lost in the Kansas Legislation by two notes. She also reads about D. Reid having to pay $2,500 on a note for his friend Thad-Walker.

entries.fullText:
Just one year ago
to day commenced my
Monroe County Business
to educate my possible
Jury-men.
To night's Telegrams say
Senator Sumner died at 3 P.M. to day - Was
in the Senate yesterday - the noblest Roman of all
the senators - he was
true to the negro - but never
uttered a public word for
Equal rights to women -
How I [have] plead with
him last January - & three years
ago - he admitted that his principles
logically carried out gave women
equal guarantee with man.
Ex President Filmore buried to day -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony reflects on her Monroe County Business and laments the death of Senator Sumner, who never publicly advocated for equal rights for women.

entries.fullText: Heard M.N. Mann preach _ "Quit yourselves like men" _ Illustrated true manliness of Charles Sumner _ a beautiful and deserved tribute.
entries.summaryText: M.N. Mann preached about true manliness and paid tribute to Charles Sumner.

entries.fullText: Mother better today _ attended a Masque party at E.A. Marsh's this evening _
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony's mother is feeling better and she attended a Masque party at E.A. Marsh's.

entries.fullText:
[Woman Suffrage Reception
at Mrs. Marsh
No. 8 Francis Street]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attended a Woman Suffrage Reception at Mrs. Marsh's house located at No. 8 Francis Street.

entries.fullText:
Opening reception
of Sister Marys new
school House - [u.a.?]
now Madison Park school
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attended the opening reception of Sister Mary's new school house, which is now known as Madison Park school.

entries.fullText:
Woman Suffrage
Sociable at house
of E. A. Marsh -
Mrs Stanton arrived at
midnight-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about a sociable at E. A. Marsh's house for Woman Suffrage where Mrs. Stanton arrived at midnight.

entries.fullText:
Women's Temperance
meeting in Corinthian
Hall called for to
night - was postponed
because matters were
not fully matured-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about a Women's Temperance meeting that was postponed due to matters not being fully matured.

entries.fullText:
Mrs Stanton
took the 10.30 A.M
train for Detroit -
Wendell went depot
with her-
entries.summaryText: Mrs Stanton took a train to Detroit accompanied by Wendell.

entries.fullText: MARCH FRIDAY, 27 1874

Attended womens
temperance meet'g at the
Central Church lecture
room at 2 P.M - after
it called with Mrs R.S. Tery
on Mrs. Dr. Matthews, S. J. Patern,
& Mrs D. Celling to see if they
would serve as officers - all
declined - reached
home late - too late
to attend the Hampton
Va. Negro school. -
Concert at Corinthian
Hall - but found
Brother Aaron gone
with Miss Ellen E. Baker
For the first time since
the death of my dear sister
Gula - Flashed over me the
possibility of brother A's [?]
a young girl - the possibility that
another [???] children might
share dear Gulas [?]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attended a women's temperance meeting and tried to recruit officers for the organization. She was unable to attend the Hampton Va. Negro school and instead went to a concert at Corinthian Hall. She thought about the possibility of her brother Aaron being with a young girl and having children like her late sister Gula.

entries.fullText:
Staid home
all day & [?]ike
Da[??]her's Ghost -
the one forbidden
thought [???]
[????]. M[??] [???] hep[???]
my weary eyes -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony stayed home all day and had thoughts about a forbidden subject.

entries.fullText: It may be small, it may be selfish, or it may be mean - but I cannot bear to see another woman wedging herself into the place of my dear sister Gula - How can man so stash[?] to allow it - it hurts every fibre of my nature, p[???] as such action would my dear sister's - if she were alive -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony expresses her frustration at seeing another woman taking her sister's place.

entries.fullText:
Hulah Anthony came & staid with Mother - I attended women's T. meet'gs
it held late - went to Maggies to dinner - - my heart ached - went back to Nants[?] to see the Pencil picture he is making of sister Gula - it was so very unsatisfactory - the tears would come - I then rushed out and took car to Mt. Hope - what buried hopes - lie in our lot - In my agony I could not wish one loved one back - any that we who remain might so conduct ourselves as to leave a like worthy record -
Sleep seems fleeing from me - heaven & the dear spirits help me to bear whatever is to come,
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends time with family and friends, sees a disappointing picture of her sister, and reflects on the importance of leaving a worthy record.

entries.fullText: APRIL THURSDAY, 2 1874

Ran down to
Maggies after dinner
found George just leaving -
Maggie on the lounge
with severe head-ache
- Dr. Hurd called it acute
Catorah - A. came
in before I left -
entries.summaryText: Susan visits Maggie and finds her with a severe headache. Dr. Hurd diagnoses it as acute Catorah. A. also comes to visit.

entries.fullText:
Sister Hannah &
self ran down to Maggie's
found her better -
Couch carried a
pine plant pie.
One there A- there
[???]
first time he has
walked with me
or seen me since
Gula's death-
entries.summaryText: Sister Hannah and Susan B. Anthony visit Maggie and find her in better health. They bring a pine plant pie. A person identified as A- is also present, the first time he has seen Susan since Gula's death.

entries.fullText:
Mother sitting up two
or three hours at a time-
but has not improved
very much since last
Sunday- seems almost
at a stand still-
Maggie a little
better this A.M.- aaron
went down to see- children
both better- George has
sick head-ache
Eugene came home unexpectedly
last night--Mr Hawley
took Miss Baker to Episcopal
Church- Snowing at evening
Finished reading aloud,
to mother, Ms L.D. Blakes
"Fettered for Life"- it will stimu
late every girl reader to have
something beside marriage to
depend on for support-
wrote letters & sent Call
for May anniversary all the
P.M. and evening-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony provides an update on the health of her mother and Maggie. She also mentions the unexpected return of Eugene and various social activities. She finishes reading "Fettered for Life" to her mother and spends the rest of the day writing letters and preparing for the May anniversary.

entries.fullText:
Temperance meeting at
2 this P.M - was present
a short time - good audience -
Resolved to send committees to
Board of Excise - & Police
Commissioners -
Mother seems stronger
to day than any day before -
What can marriage
be to a mere thing of comfort
& accommodation as to
this worlds wants - To take
a new wife seems admission
that the former was not the true
spiritual mate - else that
polygamy is the true theory -
Sent of Calls to N.Y.
profers - & wrote my
letters yesterday to day -
entries.summaryText: Attended a temperance meeting and sent committees to Board of Excise and Police Commissioners. Contemplated the purpose of marriage and sent letters to N.Y. offers.

entries.fullText: At eve'g called at Lotte Anthony's Home all day - letter from Mrs Morton saying she had engaged to into Michigan & should not be at our New York May meeting - I prid back hat shot - but under by saying if she could afford to desert our national ship at this hour - we could afford to let her
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony receives a letter from Mrs. Morton saying she will not be attending the New York May meeting and writes about it in her journal.

entries.fullText: Mission Society of the 8th ward at Madison Park school- this evening- Received invitation from Jenny Marsh Parker to speak at the Central Aid Conference this evening- proposing to establish work by which the poor may earn their support- Maggie called in P.M.- first in s long time- Mary Reed Horn called- looked miserable- 2nd baby well along- though not 2 years married until January-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends the Mission Society of the 8th ward and receives an invitation to speak at the Central Aid Conference. She also receives visits from Maggie and Mary Reed Horn.

entries.fullText: Mission society of the 8th Ward at Madison Park school this evening - Received invitation from Jenny March Parker to speak at the Central and Bon[???] this evn'g - proposing to establish work by which the poor may earn their support - Maggie called in P.M. - first in a long time - May Reed Horn called - looks miserable - 1st baby well along - though not 2 years married until January
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends the Mission Society of the 8th ward and receives an invitation to speak at the Central and Bon[???]. She also receives visits from Maggie and May Reed Horn.

entries.fullText: Mother slowly improving all these days
entries.summaryText: Susan's mother is slowly improving.
Susan wrote nothing on this day.

entries.fullText: Wrote 20 letters today -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote 20 letters on April 12th, 1874.

entries.fullText: Ran over to the Asbury M.E. Church in P.M. to Women's Temperance meeting - they begin to get hold of the work some - to see how very little power women have. - that the ballot in their hands will open eyes of officials- much more quickly than prayers-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attended a Women's Temperance meeting at Asbury M.E. Church on April 13th, 1874 and discussed the power of women and the importance of the ballot.

entries.fullText:
Wrote 20 letters
to day - - went down
to niece Maggies in the
evening - they decided to take
Bennetts House north at Paul st
- terrible cut down to have
Maggie & the little boys so far away
entries.summaryText: Went to Maggie's house and wrote 20 letters.

entries.fullText:
Wrote 30 letters to
Officers National W. S. A., to day,
enclosing call for anniversary -
Letter from B. F. Butler
saying the D.C. Suffarge bill
report would only be presented
this session
entries.summaryText: Wrote 30 letters and received a letter from B. F. Butler regarding the D.C. Suffrage bill report.

entries.fullText:
Beautiful spring day -
D. H. Day and St. John of St. Louis from
Industrial Congress sitting here called
this A.M -
Letter from Sarah J. Spencer
of D. C. Reform school for girls
and D. C. Suffrage bill -
sent Stillman note to
A. E. J. - 1122 Vine st - Phila -
to day - by her order through
her agent O. G. Bernard -
198 - 8th st New York
The note is paid and receipted -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony receives a letter from Sarah J. Spencer regarding the D.C. Reform school for girls and D.C. Suffrage bill. She also sends a note to A. E. J. through her agent O. G. Bernard.

entries.fullText:
Trial pamphlets done
to day - mailed copy to Mrs. Gage
Hooker & Stanton -
Dropped into Industrial
Congress - gave me privilege of the
floor and invited me to speak - told
them degraded labor of women made
them quite as heavy a milstone round
working mens necks as that of
the "Heathen Chinese" -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony mails trial pamphlets to Mrs. Gage, Hooker, and Stanton. She also speaks at the Industrial Congress about the degraded labor of women.

entries.fullText:
Mother moved into
J.R.'s bedroom to stay while
repairs are made above
and below - then she is to
go down into front parlor
- Aaron up into Mother's room
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony's mother moved into J.R.'s bedroom temporarily due to repairs.

entries.fullText:
Went to Central
Church this evening to
hear Rev. Ida Fishers
sermon on Temperance
and women's part in it.
First heat - went alone
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attended a sermon on Temperance and women's role in it at Central Church given by Rev. Ida Fisher.

entries.fullText:
Ellen J Baker went
to Naples to spend vacation
- Carpenter came - &
general tearing up beginning
entries.summaryText: Ellen J Baker went to Naples for vacation and Carpenter arrived, causing a general commotion.

entries.fullText:
Women's Temperance
meeting Corinthian Hall
Dr Anderson + others - packed
hall - Sister H. & self went -
entries.summaryText: Attended Women's Temperance meeting at Corinthian Hall with Dr Anderson and others. The hall was packed. Sister H. and Susan B. Anthony also attended.

entries.fullText:
Beautiful day -
was down town -
called on Sarah
Owen
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony had a beautiful day and visited Sarah Owen in town.

entries.fullText:
Letter came from
D. A. with $500 interest
money to mother -
reports little since sick
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony received a letter from D. A. with $500 interest money for her mother and reports on someone being sick.

entries.fullText:
Mother had severe
attack of pain through right
shoulder - which made it impossible
for her to lie down - so sat
up & rested head on arm chair
with pillow - - - no relief
until after breakfast - - -
then quite smart again -
- Snow a foot deep last
night - Mother, with wish
of May & Hannah & consent of
Aaron cancelled my $1000. note
in consideration of my staying at
home through the illness of
herself & sister Gula during
1873-1874
entries.summaryText: Mother had a severe attack of pain, but later recovered. May, Hannah, and Aaron cancelled her $1000 note.

entries.fullText:
Did not attend
the women's Temperance
meeting this P.M.
entries.summaryText: Missed the women's Temperance meeting.

entries.fullText: APRIL TUESDAY, 28 1874

Mother moved down
into Parlor about 10 this
morning - walked almost
alone down back stairs -
Dr. Dio Lewis called. I went to
Central Church at evening to
hear him - the same old
story. Man make & break
laws - & women by love &
persuasion soften their
hearts to abandon the wickedness
- not a hint that women should
assume ballot & make & execute laws
Mary slept in dear Gulas bedroom
on a new single bedstead, hair
matress _
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her mother moving down into the parlor and Dr. Dio Lewis calling. She also attended a speech by Dr. Dio Lewis at Central Church in the evening. Mary slept in Gulas bedroom.

entries.fullText:
Mother fell about
7 o'clock this A.M. in
getting back into bed - hit
her head, hard - but
still did not feel
very much hurt
entries.summaryText: Mother fell out of bed and hit her head, but did not feel much hurt.

entries.fullText:
Mother bright -
Sat up until 2 P.M.
& then laid down two
hours & up again -
Letter from brother
D. R. and Merritt - all
well - D.R. wants Merritt
to work for him
entries.summaryText: Mother is feeling better. Received a letter from brother D. R. and Merritt, who is being asked to work for D. R.

entries.fullText:
Annual meeting -
Ms Stanton to be there -
Went down town
to Miss Larsons - &
came home discouraged
about clothes -
Sister Mary said there
must be a new cheap
travelling dress & sallied
out & found a dress
maker - Miss Nelly -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about attending an annual meeting in Michigan W. S. State where Ms Stanton was supposed to be present. She also went to Miss Larsons and Sister Mary suggested finding a new cheap travelling dress, which they found with Miss Nelly.

entries.fullText:
Went down
town - bought
an Alpaca - three
grey stripes & black -
Miss Nelly came
at noon -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony went to town and bought an Alpaca with three grey stripes and black. Miss Nelly came at noon.

entries.fullText: Working the order of the day Miss Kelly & Mrs Logan both sewing on my dress to day
entries.summaryText: Miss Kelly and Mrs Logan sewed on Susan's dress.

entries.fullText: Paper Hanger in front Chamber - Brother A. came up at 2 & helped put down his carpet - Got the room settled - so he & his darling little Kay slept in it this night Miss Kelly worked all day for me - travelling dress announced by all a success -
entries.summaryText: Brother A. helped with the room and Miss Kelly worked on Susan's dress which was a success.

entries.fullText:
Mary & Seth both
worked until 2 P.M.
getting my room & south
bedroom to rights - so
she would not have
to work after I leave -
- Aaron took little Kay
to their new home 183
South St Paul St - & staid
there to dinner
Mother went out &
ate dinner at table
with us - the first time
in nearly six months -
it did seem good
entries.summaryText: Mary, Seth, Aaron, Kay, and Mother spent the day together. Aaron took little Kay to their new home. Mother ate dinner with them for the first time in nearly six months.

entries.fullText:
Left home at 10 A.M. -
- first for three months -
If Mother can only be careful
& quiet - but she so longs to
see everything & do something -
It seems sad enough to leave
them so long - only Aaron
& Mother & Mary - Miss
Baker board there - but we
cannot take her into our
hearts as one of family some
way - though nice, sweet,
pleasant - too self conscious
to be acceptable -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left home for the first time in three months. She expressed concern for her family and described her feelings towards Miss Baker, who boards with them.

entries.fullText:
Left Belvidere House
this A.M. - too much
Lager beer, Tobacco smoke
& Onions smell - finally
settled at Westminster - room
197 - $2. per day -
Saw Mrs. Hallock & Phelps
both promised to come this eve
to work up report - Mrs
Blake too occupied - but
none came -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left Belvidere House and settled at Westminster. She saw Mrs. Hallock and Phelps who promised to come that evening to work up a report, but they did not come.

entries.fullText:
At Westminster
Mr & Mrs Rose called
- glad enough to see
the grand old pioneer
once more -
Rev. Olympia Brown
arrived at noon - so
hope of force enough
to go though the
Convention comes with her
Preliminary meeting
at Mrs R. Logier's this
P.M. -
Mrs Mather
Wright called at
Westminster - she stops
at St Nicholas -
at 10 P.M -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was at Westminster where Mr. and Mrs. Rose called. Rev. Olympia Brown arrived at noon and there was hope of force enough to go through the Convention. There was a preliminary meeting at Mrs. R. Logier's in the afternoon. Mrs. Mather Wright also called at Westminster and she stops at St. Nicholas.

entries.fullText: Anniversary meeting of the National Woman Suffrage Association Preliminary meeting at 10 A.M. - First session of Con. at 2 P.M., very fair audience of excellent people - Mrs Rose sat on platform as of old - it was such a strength Antoinette Brown Blackwell sent note that she would speak for us - first time since 1869.
entries.summaryText: Anniversary meeting of the National Woman Suffrage Association.

entries.fullText: National W. S. A. Annual meeting - Irving Hall - New - York - Audience larger - but no letter from Mrs Stanton - though she promised sure to send one back - to compensate in a measure for her absence - O. B. Trothingham A. L. Brown Blackwell spoke this P.M. - Ms M. C. Wright made President for coming year
entries.summaryText: National W. S. A. Annual meeting at Irving Hall in New York.

entries.fullText:
Settled up at
West Minster - & moved
to Dr. Loziers - it is
a shame - that I spent
at Hotels $22 - I did it
to be with the strangers
who should come - & not
one some Olympia Brown
stopped with me - so
lost my cash & gained
no society of friends -
rained all day -
Letter from sister Mary
Mother keeps smart -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony settles up in West Minster and moves to Dr. Loziers. She spent $22 at hotels to be with strangers but lost her cash and gained no society of friends. She received a letter from her sister Mary and her mother is doing well.

entries.fullText:
New York -
at noon called
at Dr. Millers - 41 West 45th
Tam ? Dr. J. C. Jackson Jr. - &
Geo. F. Fraser - there to
Brooklyn - met C. A.
Studwell - his wife died
a year ago - then to
Cousin Samantha [?]
to diner - 146 Jeroleman St
- Cousin Ellen Syrier
came after dinner - but
oh the Smoke smoke -
Henry, Susan & Johnny - all
together the sitting perfectly
saturated & nauseating
every breath - How can
women endure such smells
a life time - slept in
Grandma Taphorn's bed - that
was saturated with snuff
as well as smoke from the
sitting room - had a good visit
with Nellie & Samantha in
spite of smells -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Dr. Millers, Dr. J. C. Jackson Jr., and Geo. F. Fraser in New York before going to Brooklyn to meet C. A. Studwell. She then goes to Cousin Samantha's house for dinner and meets Cousin Ellen Syrier. She complains about the smoke and smells in the sitting room and sleeps in Grandma Taphorn's bed, which is saturated with snuff and smoke. She has a good visit with Nellie and Samantha despite the smells.

entries.fullText:
Called on Mrs Rose
Spent two hours very
pleasantly - & bade
her good bye - probably
the last parting in this
world - & she thinks
there will be no meeting
in the next - but I hope
& believe she will find that
there is life beyond the river
of death- She sails for
England the 30th next - She
is a glorious spirit -
Dined at dear Mrs Loziers,
called on Mrs Phelps, then
Mrs Blaked & dined at
Cousin Geo. Caldwells, & to
Depot at 8 & Bridgeport at 10,
and to Rev. Olympia Browns
Ready to begin Connecticut
work on the morrow
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Mrs. Rose and other acquaintances in Connecticut before beginning work there.

entries.fullText:
New Milford
Hall -
stopped at Mrs Electra
Thayer’s - widow - her
daughter Emily A. Thayer
a Teacher - the son Mr.
Edward Thayer got
up lecture— Mr &
Mrs Middlebrook went over
to lecture —, I was
feeling very tired - and
great irritation of stomach
- went to bed, slept
two hours, more—
Had fine audience of
the very best people - &
all seemed delighted —
// Voted “solid aye that
Legislature should either
enfranchise women or
exempt them from
taxation — //.
Mrs A. E. Pixley (Milliner)
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends a lecture and speaks to an audience in New Milford, Connecticut, and votes on a legislative issue.

entries.fullText:
Newton CT -
Sanford Hall - Central Hotel
Salmon Peck - Port master
& daughter May Frances Peck -
rode past on noon train
to Bridgeport - no letters there -
In A.M. Ms Hager
took me to call on Mr
P. F. Shroeder - has elegant
paintings ancestors portraits
& fine garden & hot house
flowers
Went to Newtown at
5.30 - shower came up
at 7, just the time farmers
would start for lecture
result was small audience
Charles C. Slabin
Lanesville, Litch Co. CT
Subscribed for Mrs. Wister new
paper The Crusader-
& is one of the old
abolitionists of Ct-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Newton CT, calls on Mr. P. F. Shroeder, and attends a small lecture in Newtown.

entries.fullText:
Narrgatruck- Ct-
Mr. George Hine- gave his
Hall- free of charge-
Mr H.A. Baldwin sold tickets-
Rainy day & lack of through
notice gave small audience
Both Mr Hine & Mr
Baldwin expressed great
satisfaction with lecture-
Went down to Bridgeport
on 6 A.M. train & stopped
with Olympia Brown until 6 P.M.
Found no letters from
home- wrote my first long
one here to day- I feel uneasy
& anxious to hear from all of
them especially Mother-
H.C. Baldwin is a
young lawyer & friendly-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends a lecture in Narrgatruck- Ct- and visits Bridgeport to stay with Olympia Brown.

entries.fullText:
- Wooster Hall - stopped
at Mr Nathan R. Wooster
- wife Mrs Antoinette Wooster
-- Found no notice whatever
--Express agent had failed to
deliver the posters - though
they had been in office two
weeks & more - directed to
Antoinette Wooster - clearly -
- at last they came round
this P.M.- to get 500 little
dodgers printed- boys to scatter
them & myself went to the
schools & gave notice -
The day is beautiful -
Olympia Brown came at
6 P.M. - had small audience
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony stopped at Wooster Hall in Seymour CT and had trouble with the delivery of posters. She eventually got them printed and distributed them with the help of some boys. Olympia Brown came to visit in the evening.

entries.fullText:
Went with Olympia to
Bridgeport on 9 A.M.
train - in P.M. rode out
on street car & called on
P.T. Barnum - what
a splendid house and grounds
& equipage - only himself &
tenants to enjoy it & he
seems incompetent to enjoy
so eaten out by money grasping -
no soul, no interest in any
thing now but his Hippodrome
show - I left sad &
strolled through his grounds
and sea side park - & drank
in the sea breeze - found
a package from sister Mary -
on return- & glad was I to
get note of mother - she keeps
about the same - a little stronger
Mary says -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony went to Bridgeport with Olympia Brown and visited P.T. Barnum's house and grounds. She found him to be consumed by money and lacking in soul. She received a package from her sister Mary and a note about her mother's health.

entries.fullText:
Attended Olympias church with A.M. using a
text "God is not the the
god of the dead, but of the living".
the sermon far surpassed
Mrs Livermore's, an immortalist
that I heard a year ago in Chicago,
- the evening was the lesson
of the floods-- Olympia
means well, preaches
well, real sermons-
not like Unittarans lectures.
- wrote letters in P.M
home & various others-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends church and writes letters in Bridgeport CT. She compares the sermon to one she heard in Chicago and praises the preacher.

entries.fullText:
Congregational Church
Mr George L. Smith &
wife Mrs L.B. Smith made
me very welcome in their
house-- rained all day.
- audience small-
about 100- still good
for the night- everything
had been done to ensure
success- a pleasant
night only was lacking-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends a church in Plainsville, Ct and is welcomed by Mr. and Mrs. Smith. The audience is small due to the rain.

entries.fullText:
- Dr Osborne -
called at 9 A.M. -
found the Dr. had
written Olympia that
no meeting could be
had here - I had
to stop until 1 P.M.
then go to new House
Mrs Abby Barker Sheldon - No 40
York Avenue - New Haven
Mrs Comstock - 11 College St -
Hon. Henry Perry
Danbury - Ct -
Member of Ct. Legislature,
friendly to womens suffrage
- went to New Haven & called
on Mrs Comstock - staid all night
at Joseph Sheldons -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony meets with Dr. Osborne and visits Mrs. Abby Barker Sheldon and Mrs. Comstock in New Haven and stays overnight at Joseph Sheldons.

entries.fullText:
Thompsonville - Ct -
Joseph Bent -
[?] Hotel --
Mr Channery Brainard
of Chili N. Y. with his cousin
Ursula Brainard met me
at Depot, took me to C's
uncles - Brainard -
- good luck for me -
small audience -
no use to try to hold
meetings in towns where there
is not light or knowledge
on the question -
On way up from
N.H. - stopped at Hartford
& dined with the Burrs.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony meets with Joseph Bent and Mr. Channery Brainard and gives a speech to a small audience in Thompsonville, CT and dines with the Burrs in Hartford.

entries.fullText:
No meeting to night
Went down to Hartford &
stopped with the Burrs
all night -
Yesterday - the House
of Representatives discharged
the Judiciary Committee
from Women Suffrage petitions
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony went to Hartford and stayed with the Burrs. The House of Representatives discharged the Judiciary Committee from Women Suffrage petitions.

entries.fullText:
Danielsonville
J. D. A. Stone -
Stopped at Olive Branch
Hotel - a reformed
Drunkard the keeper -
Circus & show in
town so small chance
for an audience for me -
- The U. S. Senate
vote down amendment
of A. A. Sargent yesterday
to make [?] Ter. allow
woman suffrage - by 19 to
27 - -
Spoke in M. E. Church
& Pastor introduced me -
Mrs Sayles came for
me & after lecture we
went to Dayville - had
a pretty fair audience.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony stayed at the Olive Branch Hotel in Danielsonville and spoke at the M. E. Church. The U.S. Senate voted down an amendment to allow woman suffrage in [?] Ter.

entries.fullText:
Dayville -
Sayle's Hotel --
Mr. Sayles
Mrs Lita Barney Sayles -
daughters Lizzie & Ella -
9 A.M., Decoration Services at
Cemetery - Spoke of womens
part in war - -
The Congregational Pastor
Rev - E. F. M. Bateheller
invited me to give a
Temperance Lecture Sunday
A.M. in his Pulpit -
Mrs Potter - sister of Mr
Sayles - very cordial -
Had good audience
in evening - Mrs Sayles
introduced me -
Mrs S. drove me over
to Cousin Dr. [Leth?] Rogers
in P.M. to say I could
not go to them till evening Sunday
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends Decoration Services at Cemetery and is invited to give a Temperance Lecture on Sunday at the Congregational Pulpit by the Pastor.

entries.fullText:
Dayville - Ct -
at Mrs Sayles -
Congregational Pulpit in
regular sermon place -
gave Temperance lecture &
woman's way to work -
Everybody delighted - at
2 P.M. gave same Lecture
as nearly as I ever
can an extempore
talk at Williamsville
- Belle Rogers came
for me - & after dinner
I rode to Pomfret with
her - delightful ride -
found all waiting for
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony gives a Temperance lecture and a talk on woman's way to work at the Congregational Pulpit and later gives the same lecture at Williamsville.

entries.fullText:
Rode to post office
with cousin Hannah
entries.summaryText: Rode to post office with cousin Hannah

entries.fullText:
At Cousin Seth Rogers
Niece Maggie, McLain
and husband west
for Cincinnati, Leavenworth,
Denver &-
entries.summaryText: Visited Cousin Seth Rogers with Niece Maggie, McLain and husband west planning to travel to Cincinnati, Leavenworth, Denver and other places.

entries.fullText:
at Rev Olympia Brown
& John Henry Willis' home
wrote 9 long letters
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote 9 long letters at Rev Olympia Brown and John Henry Willis' home.

entries.fullText:
mailed 64 - Trials -
20 to J.P. Wallis - Cal -
" " C.V. Waite Chicago
" " C.H. Baker [?] CS
4 " A.P. [?] Oregon
Postage $3.40
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony mailed 64 Trials and spent $3.40 on postage, sending 20 to J.P. Wallis in Cal, 20 to C.V. Waite in Chicago, 20 to C.H. Baker [?] CS, and 4 to A.P. [?] Oregon.

entries.fullText: Listened to Rev. Olympia Brown preaching in A.M. [?] The [?] - oneness of God- - at evening- I spoke on Temperance in Mrs Brown's pulpit- Had an immense jam- & hundreds went away unable to get in- Took some points as at Williamsonville a week ago- - but somehow, my tongue would not go off freely- - had closest of attention- & people seemed satisfied still I could not feel so-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony listened to Rev. Olympia Brown in the morning and spoke on Temperance in the evening at Mrs. Brown's pulpit. She had an immense jam and hundreds went away unable to get in.

entries.fullText: Took Housatonick Train at 10.30 for Albany- - had delightful ride up the valley of the H. river - were rains last night & great flood- the H.R.R. shops dam carried off- - reached Albany 4.30 found Lydia Mott not so weak as I feared- still very feeble - & very poor to what she was last January-- better She & Jane seemed very glad to see me. also Phebe H. Jones- the latter in the midst of house cleeaning & painting & papering & house full of boarders-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony took the Housatonick Train to Albany and visited Lydia Mott, who was not as weak as feared but still very feeble. She also visited Jane and Phebe H. Jones, who was in the midst of house cleaning and had a house full of boarders.

entries.fullText:
-
Had pleasant day -
called on Phebe Jones -
Mary Barquet, Mary Tapp -
- Looked in upon
Judge Bingham &
Hon. A. J. Colvin - the
two men who pushed
the Married Women's Property
bill of 1860 through our
Legislature -
Lydia gave me a
silver gravy spoon -
a calico dress & a copy of
Uncle Tom's Cabin - given
her by William H. Tapp -
also Tennyson's Pomes
of her sister Abigails, given her
by Frederick Douglas -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony had a pleasant day in Albany, visited several people, and received gifts from Lydia and Abigails.

entries.fullText:
Albany - to Rochester
Left at 8.45 -
stopped off at Syracuse
& chatted with Mrs M.
Joslyn Gage - she seemed
more nervous & irritable
than ever - & still determined
to succeed as a
speaker - I do wish she
could do so - she has
so much knowledge of
everything belonging to our cause.
Left L. at 7 P.M. - &
arrived home at 9.55 -
- found all in bed -
send up back stairs &
into my own bed as
soon washed of cinders.
It is always to good to get
into my own humble bed
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony traveled from Albany to Rochester, stopped in Syracuse to chat with Mrs. M. Joslyn Gage, and arrived home late at night.

entries.fullText:
At Home - Rochester
no 7 Madison St -
Mother up & out
to breakfast with us -
She is very much stronger
Cousin Joseph
Hathaway's wife -
Ellen Bristol - died
this night - disease
inflamation of the
Bowels -
Took Henry down
town in P.M. & his
grandpa took him
over to his, Henry's home
183 west St Paul at --
Aaron rec'd telegram from
J.R.A. of Maggie & Georges arrival
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her day at home in Rochester, mentioning her mother's improved health, the death of Cousin Joseph Hathaway's wife, Ellen Bristol, and Aaron receiving a telegram about Maggie and Georges' arrival.

entries.fullText:
Home
visiting & talking
with Mother
At 5 P.M. walked
over to Maggie's new
home across Vincent
Street Bridge - a beautiful
view of the Falls -
Found little Tommy King
splendidly bright & sweet
but seemed not to
know me -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends time with her mother and visits Maggie's new home, where she sees little Tommy King who does not seem to recognize her.

entries.fullText:
Sister Hannah &
I went to West
Farmington - to
attend the funeral
of Ellen Hathaway -
Found Cousin
Hannah Hathaway
quite smart - & bright
as ever -
entries.summaryText: Attended the funeral of Ellen Hathaway in West Farmington with Sister Hannah and found Cousin Hannah Hathaway quite smart and bright.

entries.fullText:
West Farmington
at George Collins - the
husband of [Marrian?] Hathaway
-
Funeral at 9 P.M.
a sad bereavement -
Mother of three children
oldest girl of 12 - very
promising -
John G.
Cornell - quaker
preacher - same
man & same
sermon - only stretched
out longer - that was
at Rebecca's funeral
last October - much
repetition & very little
instruction -
entries.summaryText: Attended the funeral of the mother of three children, oldest girl of 12, in West Farmington at George Collins' house. John G. Cornell, a quaker preacher, gave the same sermon as at Rebecca's funeral last October, with much repetition and very little instruction.

entries.fullText:
Geo. Collins brought sister
H & self to call on
Cousin Judge John
[Sapham's?] widow and
[Tim?chada?, and [???ta] daughter
Ann - - Seemed
very glad to see us
took train at 8:45
all well at home
no letters
good article in last
week's Independent on
Gen. Jetter's [effort?] and
my petition to Congress
to remit my fine.
Aaron got letter from
George today. They are having a
delightful time.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Judge John [Sapham's?] widow, [Tim?chada?], and [???ta] daughter Ann. She mentions an article in last week's Independent on Gen. Jetter's [effort?] and her petition to Congress to remit her fine. Aaron got a letter from George.

entries.fullText:
Staid at home
all day. no - went
down town and helped
Sister Hannah select
a parlor carpet - green
and drab color and a
scroll pattern, very
pretty indeed.
Hannah feeling very
much oppressed
Eugene out of work
since first of May
nearly whole of last year
so she has been compelled
to draw on her
little principal for everyday
living as well as her
house repairs
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony stays at home and helps Sister Hannah select a parlor carpet. Hannah is feeling very much oppressed as Eugene has been out of work since the first of May.

entries.fullText:
One year ago this
day of the month was
my trial at Canandaigua
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony reflects on the anniversary of her trial at Canandaigua.

entries.fullText:
Rode out to our
Old farm with Mrs.
Fay(?) & little Harry - it
looks very natural & oh
so good to see -
- Letter from George
& Maggie - all well &
enjoying themselves every
minute -
Aaron took Harry up
to Spencerfort on 4.20
train to see Aunt Sarah
Perine Todd - & back at 8.
Sister May & Ellen
Baker visited no 12
school.
- Judge Hunt
ordered verdict of guilty
one year ago today -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits her old farm with Mrs. Fay and Harry, receives a letter from George and Maggie, and Aaron takes Harry to visit Aunt Sarah Perine Todd. May and Ellen Baker visit school. Anthony reflects on the anniversary of her guilty verdict.

entries.fullText:
Judge Selden appealed
for new trial & judge
Hunt denied it - &
then pronounced sentence
of $100 fine & prosecution
- after which we all
returned to Rochester -
Dear Sister Guelma
arrived at 9.50 from
New York - looking
so wasted - still seeing
very bright - she spent a
month in New Jersey -
all of us hoping against hope
that the change might help
her - but only down,
down - was the result
of that & all else until
the 9th of Nov. - then all was
over - Nov 9, 1873-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about Judge Selden's appeal for a new trial, the denial of it by Judge Hunt, and the subsequent sentence of a $100 fine and prosecution. She also writes about Sister Guelma's arrival from New York, looking wasted, after spending a month in New Jersey, and the hope that the change might help her.

entries.fullText:
At home
a sweet letter from
dear Sarah Pugh - with
a $5 greenback - For S. B.
Anthony's own self.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony receives a sweet letter from Sarah Pugh with a $5 greenback for herself.

entries.fullText: Went to a secret society- for temperance actions- politically - with Daniel M. and Lottie B. Anthony- and joined them
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony went to a secret society for temperance actions with Daniel M. and Lottie B. Anthony and joined them.

entries.fullText:
Girl- Mary Dobbin
left for a week's vacation-
9. I got my
first dinner for a
long time-
Sister Mays school
had a Strawberry
Festival this eve-
entries.summaryText: Mary Dobbin left for a week's vacation and Sister Mays school had a Strawberry Festival.

entries.fullText:
Canned 12 qts
of strawberries today-
and how much
I thought of dear
Sister Gula- her
hands used always
to do such work
entries.summaryText: Canned 12 qts of strawberries and thought of Sister Gula's hard work.

entries.fullText: Attended Unitarian Church "The law & the Judgement one with God" and with men - had reference to the Beecher Tilton scandal. Nicely drawn. None all good, nor all evil. Walked home with Maria Porter - her grief for her darling Susie Rempshall is still very fresh with her. At 6 P.M. I went to Mt. Hope. A year ago dear Sister Gula was struggling to live, to get well again. How I wonder if she & father & Thomas [?] & dear Eliza can see & know our thoughts - our fears our hopes for those left. Not for those gone Not a doubt but all is well with them.
entries.summaryText: Attended Unitarian Church and walked home with Maria Porter. Visited Mt. Hope and reflected on the Beecher Tilton scandal and the well-being of loved ones.

entries.fullText:
Cousin Cynthia
Anthony came at
noon. I went
over to W. A. Hallowells
to tea. The Dr. P. A.
Dolley there. Talked
of the Beecher
scandal. Every
body wants to be able
to forgive him, even
he has been weak
or wicked at some
unguarded hour.
entries.summaryText: Cousin Cynthia visited, talked about Beecher scandal.

entries.fullText:
Mrs. Elizabeth F. Long- of
Barry Pike Co, ill. Called
that she might say she had
seen S. B. A. Mrs. Coll. R.
Keeper of Mt. Morris
called Mrs. L.C. Smith with her
Cousin Cynthia
Anthony left at noon
for Medina
Miss E. S. Baker for
Geneva. Delhi & etc for
her vacation.
In P.M. went
over & helped sister
Hannah can 20 qts
of strawberries.
entries.summaryText: Various visitors came, Anthony left for Medina, helped sister Hannah can strawberries.

entries.fullText:
Dear Sister Gula
would have been 56 years
old to day. How short
the years seem to our
mother. She says 57
years ago the 13th of this
month. I was married
& strawberries were then
just ripe in South
Adams.
Letter from Mrs.
Isabella Beecher Hooker
today. She is travelling in
Europe.
Received Senator Carpenters
minority report in
favor of my petition
to day.
entries.summaryText: Susan writes about her sister's birthday, her mother's memories, a letter from Mrs. Isabella Beecher Hooker, and receiving Senator Carpenter's minority report.

entries.fullText:
Sarah Owen drove
round with Joseph Curtis'
carriage & took mother a
ride. Cary & self went along.
Called at Maggies new home
on North St. Paul St. Then crossed
Vincent St. Bridge. Finest
view of the falls & River
gorge. Then drove down
Lake Avenue & returned.
First time mother has been
in a carriage since the
day of Sister Gula's funeral.
Mrs. Days mother came to {?}.
Nettie Coggswell - 14 years old
died this noon of conjestion
of Bowels. Only 48 hours
since she first complained
of pain in bowels.
Rose brought little Tommy
May & Hannah over then.
Sister May & self have
done all the work this
last week.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony went on a carriage ride with her mother, Sarah Owen, and Joseph Curtis. They visited Maggies new home, crossed Vincent St. Bridge, and drove down Lake Avenue. Nettie Coggswell died of conjestion of Bowels. Rose brought little Tommy May & Hannah over. Sister May & self have done all the work this last week.

entries.fullText:
Not a letter
today nor yesterday.
Staid at home
all day. Mrs.
Jackson washed for
us. Mother feels a
little lamed from
riding, but on the
whole it did her
good.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony stayed at home all day. Mrs. Jackson washed for them. Mother feels a little lamed from riding, but on the whole it did her good.

entries.fullText: Sister Mary went to Unitarian church this A. M. I did up the work -
entries.summaryText: Sister Mary went to church and I did some work.

entries.fullText:
Maggie & George in
Cheyenne today.
May Dobbins
got back at noon
to day & was soon
installed in the
house work again.
Sister Mary & self have
done it all this
past two weeks.
entries.summaryText: Maggie and George are in Cheyenne, May Dobbins returned and Sister Mary and Susan have been doing all the house work for the past two weeks.

entries.fullText:
Sister Mary & self,
swept & dusted entire
house today.
Never went down
town all this week.
for me something
wonderful indeed.
I feel as if I had
lost view of the
outside world
altogether.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony and her sister Mary swept and dusted the entire house and did not go to town all week.

entries.fullText:
I went to Mr. Marm.
Sister H & Louise with
me. To Temperance
meeting at No. 1 Prospect
St. at 4 P.M. Dank
and musty basement hall.
Too bad & that people who
have money will provide
a better place. Then
called at William S.
Anthony's with Huldah
Anthony. The first time
though they have been married
ten years. A Mrs. Perkins
there from Minnesota.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attended a Temperance meeting at No. 1 Prospect St. with Sister H and Louise. She also visited William S. Anthony's house with Huldah Anthony and met Mrs. Perkins from Minnesota.

entries.fullText:
This is the Fifty-Seventh
anniversary of the marriage
of our Dear Father & Mother
- Father been gone over
the dark river 12 years the
25th of November next -
Mother still with us - almost
81 years old - very feeble
in health. sitting up most
of the time. walking about the
rooms below stairs - eating at
table with us - knitting a little.
very little - and reading a great
deal - - she & I have just
finished George Elliots novel
"Middlemarch" - Her memory
of what she reads is wonderful -
she has not a child who will ever
have read as much as she -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her parents' 57th wedding anniversary, her father's passing, and her mother's current health and hobbies.

entries.fullText:
[Mrs. D.M.C. Perkins
wants me speak Otsego Co.]
entries.summaryText: Mrs. D.M.C. Perkins wants me to speak in Otsego Co.

entries.fullText:
From R. to Richfield Springs
Mr. Creddy's Hall
Mrs. Rosalinda Bloomfield
Mr. Allen Bloomfield
Mrs. Geo. Johnson
Mrs. Dr. Glendorf
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony traveled from R. to Richfield Springs and attended a meeting at Mr. Creddy's Hall with Mrs. Rosalinda Bloomfield, Mr. Allen Bloomfield, Mrs. Geo. Johnson, and Mrs. Dr. Glendorf.

entries.fullText:
From R. Springs to
Cooperstown - [?] to
Skenevis -
Ms. Elizabeth Clark Thompson
Mr James Thompson
Mrs Maria Ferry
(Mrs Ellen Clark Hull
(Schuylers Lake - Otsego Co., N.Y.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her travels from R. Springs to Cooperstown and mentions the people she met along the way.

entries.fullText:
From Skevenis to
Oneonta -
Mr & Mrs E. W. Capron
at Central Hotel -
Lecture in Free Baptist Ch.
good audience
G.W. Reynolds - P. M.
and old abolitionist & W. S. Man
Mrs. Dr Eliz. D. Pope -
Mrs. Bundy - wife of Lawyer -
Here I learned that
Mrs Stanton had given
her version of Mrs
Tiltons confidences with
me to the Caprons
last march - It is
marvelous how she
has talked over this
peoples with everybody -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her travels from Skevenis to Oneonta, including a lecture she gave at the Free Baptist Church and the people she met along the way. She also mentions Mrs. Stanton's version of Mrs. Tilton's confidences with her being shared with others.

entries.fullText:
From O. to Unadilla
Mrs. Dr. Preland
Prett fair meeting
J.G. Cunningham - Assistant
Editor
entries.summaryText: Attended a fair meeting in Unadilla with Mrs. Dr. Preland and J.G. Cunningham.

entries.fullText:
From U. to Brainbridge
Prince Hall
Col. John Beverly
head of Good Templars
Mrs. Anthony Lathrop
A.C. Alverson - Lawyer
Sidney Plains
Large audience best
of the whole six nights -
Mrs. G. Prince
Mrs W. S. Sayre
" Clark - all asked
us to their houses
entries.summaryText: Attended a large meeting in Brainbridge with various notable individuals and were invited to the homes of Mrs. G. Prince, Mrs W. S. Sayre, and Clark.

entries.fullText:
At Bainbridge
Hastings Hotel -
Large Temperance
meeting at 2 P.M.,
Mrs Perkins the lecturer
I added a few words on
women's need of political [?]
to make her a moral power.
- went home & spent night
with Aaron M. Leathrop at
Bennettsville. - 3 miles - his
wife - Marrietta Crane Leathrop
his daughter is daughter of Charles
Anthony Crane, of John
Anthony, of Seth Anthony of
Delaware Co. - an uncle of his
Lewis R. Anthony lives at
Hammonton N.J.
House & everything neatest
of the neat - William
Crandall - a neighbor called
entries.summaryText: Attended a Temperance meeting and stayed with Aaron M. Leathrop in Bennettsville.

entries.fullText:
Niece Maggie & boys & the
negros - with Louise went
to the Lake this P.M.
Dan'l L. & Sarah Durbank
read of Canijoharie, Mont. Co.
arrived 6 P.M. - and
we began visiting in
earnest - but we do
miss dear sister Gula's
quiet serene presence -
- and now to have
sister Mary absent -
- well - there can be
no more of us to be & to
live here - only less -
so enjoy what we have
while we have is our
only wise course -
Letter from H. B. Stanton
saying he may be here tomorrow
night or Sunday A.M. - he is
evidently very nervous over Mrs
Stanton's interview with the
Eagle Reporter - It was too bad
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about a visit from Dan'l L. and Sarah Durbank, and a letter from H. B. Stanton expressing nervousness over an interview with the Eagle Reporter.

entries.fullText:
Beautiful day -
Breakfast at 8:30 -
very nice - Mary
Dobbins putting her best
foot forward - no one
not even Aaron went to
Church - niece Maggie
& little Harry came to
dinner - George moving
his R. R. ticket office today
so couldn't come - all
very sorry - Maggie looked
badly - had severe attack
in morning almost like the
Cholera - probably from
going in bathing at Lake
last night & getting chilled -
- Aaron & Dan'l went to Mt.
Hope in P.M. - mother put
new black & white gingham that
sister Annie sent her 2 years ago
& she did like very much
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about a beautiful day and a visit from niece Maggie and little Harry, as well as George moving his R.R. ticket office.

entries.fullText:
Mother & Aaron - [?]
& Sarah & I all dined
at Sister Hannah's -
Maggie & George failed to get
here to [?] - Dan'l L. left
on 4.20 train for home -
Sarah going to spend week
- Aaron took Sarah to
Corinthian Hall - Gilmore's
Band - Concert - George
& Maggie going too -
It is pleasant & yet
very sad to see Aaron go
with cousin Sarah - the
thought of how happy dear
Gula used to be as she
walked off with him - & how
happy & satisfied he was -
& how alone he now
must be at every turn.
Wrote sister Mary to just
Scott
entries.summaryText: Aaron takes Sarah to a concert at Corinthian Hall. Susan reflects on Gula's happiness with Aaron and how alone he must be now.

entries.fullText:
Temperance Convention
at 2 P.M. - City Hall -
One year ago to day
Mary Curtis was buried - &
niece Maggie came and
staid with her Ma - dear
Gula, for the first - talked
to her of disposition of her
things after she should pass
over the dark river-
entries.summaryText: Susan attends a Temperance Convention at City Hall and reflects on the passing of Mary Curtis and a conversation with Gula about her possessions after she passes away.

entries.fullText:
As we were at dinner
Cousin Lucius Howe,
wife & two daughters
drove up - came in
carriage from [Livia?] -
dreadfully hot & dusty -
- Marietta went to bed
& did not get up till
near right - -
entries.summaryText: Cousin Lucius Howe and family visit from Livia.

entries.fullText:
(Monday - 24th) -
Angeline of the
Union, called with the
Brooklyn Eagle of Saturday
with "Bessie's" testimony in
full - saying she had noticed
intimacy of Tilton for a great
many ladies - particularly Stanton
& Anthony - everybody who
refused to aid Beecher, or
blacken Tilton - is to be
make wholly bad - - It
is wonderful - that two such
loving people should fall to
abusing each other as do
