T. & E. Hilton - too bad, too bad
Of course both he & she
were very friendly, loving to me
& I to them - they seemed like
beautiful children to me
______________
This Wednesday ev'g paper
had notice of J. M. Curtis marriage
to 3d woman - last Monday the 24th
Why so late in announcing it?
entries.summaryText: Angeline shares testimony about Tilton's infidelity and Beecher's scandal. J. M. Curtis' marriage is announced late.

entries.fullText:
About 10:30 - brother
Aaron came in with
Cousin Samantha Vail
Lapham & husband
Henry G. Lapham -
they staid to dinner &
took 6 P.M. train to
Buffalo - - had a
good visit - Sister H
came in & visited while
I got the dinner -
The Democrat &
Chronicle of this A.M.
had good item on the
"Bessie" testimony - the
N. Y. Herald also - it
shows the value of
having lived an open
above board life - & yet there
are very little incidents in
my experience that evilly
construed- might be so
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony had visitors and talks about a newspaper article on the "Bessie" testimony.

entries.fullText:
Nearly all papers declare
Beechers explanation a
perfect vindication -
perhaps it ought to be thus
accepted - but alas alas -
none such would be
enough - if the accused
had been a woman -
Rev, Mr. Mann - Unitarian
Minister called this A.M. -
- Julia Wilhour of Washington
dined - Cousin Sarah
Read left on 10 train -
Cousin Sarah's weekly
visit has been very
satisfactory - we have
read & talked & enjoyed
- Hawthorne's Scarlet
Letter read aloud
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony talks about the Beecher explanation and visitors she had, including Cousin Sarah Read's weekly visit.

entries.fullText:
Took Tea at
Hallowells with
Frederick Douglass
- he walked home with
me - had good
visit -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony had tea with Frederick Douglass at Hallowells and they had a good visit.

entries.fullText: Now comes the Jersey City News Pomeroy Rev. John S.C. Glendenning - case perfectly atrocious- Then too a Methodist minister incest with his own daughter- & father of her child The fact is man as a a rule does not feel it a sin & crime to posses the body of a woman save out in lawful marriage- his crime is being exposed in the act not in committing it
entries.summaryText: Journal entry discussing a news article about a case involving a Methodist minister committing incest with his own daughter.

entries.fullText: Mailed 20 copies trial to Sarah Wallis & 10 to Mrs. E. Pitts Stevens. Parker Pillsbury arrived at 6 P.M and George, Maggie, little Thomas King came to tea with us- it was so good to see Maggie drop in so once more Aaron's cousin Melissa McLean (Uncle Lewis daughter) - and husband came to dinner So I had pretty close run - getting dinner but all pretty good
entries.summaryText: Journal entry discussing mailing copies of a trial and having guests over for tea and dinner.

entries.fullText:
Parker Pillsbury to
preach in Unitarian church
good audience in
A.M. "Free Religion- what
it is not & what it is-
-Whole time given to the
what it is not & only one
paragraph to what it is-
-terribly grand setting forth
of superstition & bigotry
- a packed house in
the ev'g - his temperance
lecture digs deep down
he is a masterly brain
entries.summaryText: Parker Pillsbury preached about Free Religion in a Unitarian church to a good audience. He talked about what it is not and only briefly mentioned what it is. He also gave a temperance lecture in the evening to a packed house.

entries.fullText:
Reception at Amy
Posts for P.P.
A goodly couple
there-
Letter from
Mary Robbins- the
girl- that she wont
be back until Saturday
of this week- while
gives a pretty bad
run of housework-
entries.summaryText: There was a reception for Parker Pillsbury at Amy Posts' house. Mary Robbins sent a letter saying she won't be back until Saturday and there is a lot of housework to be done.

entries.fullText:
Dined at Hallowells
with P.P. - - sister
Hannah got a letter that
Louise had fallen & hurt
arm & she went direct to
Marion - - A good
audience to hear Mr.
Pillsbury - his exposition
of woman's utter degradation
in marriage was terrible-
- This lecture like all of his
fails to elucidate the better
system - truer principle _ he
dwells on the old & evil &
presents the minutest details
- & then says true marriage
is union of soul, heart, & needs
no law - makes no illustration
nor elaboration of his
affirmation- he tears
down- but does not build up
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony dined with P.P. and sister. Hannah got a letter that Louise had fallen and hurt her arm and went directly to Marion. She attended a lecture by Mr. Pillsbury on the degradation of women in marriage, but Susan felt that he failed to present a better system.

entries.fullText:
No Mary Dobbins yet-
So drudging through the three
meals a day- -
Niece Maggie
& George & two boys drove up- all
had been at Mt. Hope - Little
Harry staid all night- at
tea table- Grandpa asked
Harry to guess who was coming
home tomorrow- somebody that he takes school. he guessed
that May- no- then Jenny
Hughes - - & at last Cozzy -
showing what was uppermost
in the older was last in the
younger - It gave such
a hurt, as that of last winter
- The going to negro concert with her
- Heaven grant me may
be spared any such bar
between him & his Maggie &
as- it would be the last
ounce-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony's niece Maggie, George, and two boys visited after being at Mt. Hope. Harry stayed overnight. Grandpa asked Harry to guess who was coming home tomorrow, and after guessing May and Jenny Hughes, Cozzy was revealed. Susan reflects on the hurt caused by going to a negro concert with Cozzy.

entries.fullText:
Had Mrs Dowman to
help me - the added
ounce came - when a note
from Sup't Ellis said I
must go down to his office
to Principals meeting at 4 p.m.
-- On return found
Miss Daker arrived - Mrs
Hallowell had waited an
hour for me - presently
Miss Merriman arrived -
first impression of her
good - I like her -
Postal this A.M.
from May - dated Mainstown[?]
Cal - saying I must
go into her school, take
charge till she comes -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her day, including a note from Sup't Ellis, meeting Miss Daker, Mrs Hallowell, Miss Merriman, and a postal from May.

entries.fullText:
Sister Hannah & self went
to Unitarian Church - heard Pastor -
Mr. N. Mann -- engaged 1/2 [of]
a seat - $27 - per year -
Brother Aaron went to Plymouth
Church - the first time, he said,
since the 2nd Sunday of last February
Miss Daker & Miss Merrison
went to the Central Church -
No Mary Dobbins yet - so
went through with entire
work - save Mother's help -
she washed the dishes - & I
wiped them - - Dr. Allen
called to take brother Aaron a
ride - A. was over to Maggies
Mr Hawley spent the even'g
with Miss Daker -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about attending church, her brother Aaron going to church for the first time in months, and Dr. Allen taking Aaron for a ride.

entries.fullText:
got Breakfast -& with mothers
help washed dishes- and got
to sister May's School- No. 2
at 8.46 - got along
very well
Mary Dobbins
got back at noon -
just after I left for
school
entries.summaryText: Breakfast with mothers, helped wash dishes, went to sister May's School- No. 2, got along well, Mary Dobbins was there, got back at noon.

entries.fullText:
In School
again- all day
Sister Mary got
home at 5 P.M.
well & all glad enough
to see her back again
entries.summaryText: In school all day, Sister Mary got home at 5 P.M. and everyone was glad to see her back.

entries.fullText:
Sister Mary took
her place in school
this A.M. & I have
been in a state of
perfect collapse
after her tremendous
stretch of the last two
weeks - - Cousin
Nancy Howe Clark &
daughter Emily Clark
Griggs here to dinner
Left- on 3 P.M. train
for Phelps- Aaron reported
Little Harry Baker ill-
Letter from A. J. Grover
of Earlville Ill urging me to
make a public statement
of Mrs. Tilton's confession.
entries.summaryText: Sister Mary took her place in school, Cousin Nancy Howe Clark and daughter Emily Clark Griggs visited, and a letter from A. J. Grover of Earlville Ill urging me to make a public statement of Mrs. Tilton's confession.

entries.fullText:
In a state of
collapse almost
with hired girl
in kitchen & Sister
Mary in school
entries.summaryText: In a state of collapse almost with hired girl in kitchen & Sister Mary in school.

entries.fullText: Sister Hannah & self attended Unitarian Church - Paid my first $10. for pew sent- Father paid as much for me in 1852 & 53 - when Rev W. Henry Charing preacher here in the Old U. Church
entries.summaryText: Attended Unitarian Church with Sister Hannah and paid for pew.

entries.fullText: Dewitt & Mary Ann McLean - (Pitcher) and Dr James Savage & wife - Jane Perine of Argyle - arrived on the 9 P. M. Train Dreadful hot day - I swept the house & set things in order from top to bottom
entries.summaryText: Received visitors from Argyle and cleaned the house on a hot day.

entries.fullText:
Dr. Savage & wife
went to Batavia in
A.M. --
Aaron & Dewitt &
Mary Ann & self went
to Mt Hope -- but
a shower came &
cut short our stay
entries.summaryText: Dr. Savage and his wife went to Batavia while Aaron, Dewitt, Mary Ann, and Susan went to Mt Hope but had to cut their stay short due to a shower.

entries.fullText:
Dewitt, Mary A,
Sister Mary--Miss
Baker & self went
to the State Fair
this A.M--& at
2 P.M. D.M.A., and
Aaron & self dined
at niece Maggies--
--then M.A. & self
called at Mrs Kate
Blackford's -- the first
time I had seen her
since Sister Gula's
death--
entries.summaryText: Susan and several others went to the State Fair in the morning, then had lunch with Aaron at Maggie's, and later visited Mrs. Kate Blackford for the first time since Sister Gula's death.

entries.fullText:
Dr. Savage & wife
returned at 10:20,
they with Dewitt &
Aaron. Mary Ann
& self took at the
Blackfords - every
thing very nice.
But how our
dear Gula's
absence is felt
at every step &
every place
entries.summaryText: Dr. Savage and his wife return from a visit with Dewitt and Aaron. Mary Ann and Susan B. Anthony visit the Blackfords and miss their friend Gula.

entries.fullText:
Dr. & wife &
Dewitt went to
state fair in A. M.
and at 1:15 Mrs. Savage,
Mary Ann & Dewitt
& self went to
Spencerport to
visit Sarah Perine
Todds - had very
pleasant visit
& returned at 8.
Dr. Savage & wife
took night train for
east- delayed- & they
had to wait in Depot
until 1 1/2 a.m.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony and her friends visit the state fair and then Spencerport to visit Sarah Perine Todds. Dr. Savage and his wife leave for the east but are delayed and have to wait at the Depot until 1 1/2 a.m.

entries.fullText:
At 2.20 P.M.
Dewitt and Aaron and
Mary Ann and self
went to the Lake
returned to tea
at 7.30 - at home -
this A.M.'s Associated
Press reports give brief
of Theodore Tilton's
second statement- &
eving papers still run
- my letter to Mrs
Hooker on Beecher's
denial of Woodhull
story of him 16/17
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony goes to the lake with Dewitt, Aaron, and Mary Ann and later reads about Theodore Tilton's second statement and her letter to Mrs. Hooker on Beecher's denial of Woodhull's story.

entries.fullText:
Went to Plymouth
Church with Aaron
Dewitt & Mary Ann-
- heard Dr. Strong-
Pres. of Theological Seminary
- George & Maggie
& dear little boys
here to dinner-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony goes to Plymouth Church with Aaron, Dewitt, and Mary Ann and later has George, Maggie, and their children over for dinner.

entries.fullText:
Campbell McLean
(Son of Dr. Wm. McLean)
and wife & daughter
to dinner & spent night
entries.summaryText: Campbell McLean, son of Dr. Wm. McLean, and his family had dinner and spent the night.

entries.fullText:
Campbell McLean & family
left for Fondulac Wisconsin
their home-- Dewitt &
Mary Ann took same train
for Batavia- I had
planned to go, but learned
that Amanda Billings Merriam
of Cincinnati was at niece
Maggie's- so went there to
dinner & visit with her
Mother felt lonely,
to have me start out -
it is very little
society that any of
us are for her.
entries.summaryText: Campbell McLean and his family left for their home in Fondulac Wisconsin. Dewitt and Mary Ann took the same train for Batavia. Susan B. Anthony had planned to go but instead visited Amanda Billings Merriam in Cincinnati who was at her niece Maggie's. Susan's mother felt lonely and wanted her to start out. There is very little society for any of them.

entries.fullText:
Went to Batavia on
10 A.M. train- found
Mary McLeans husband
Rob't Maxwell at Depot
for me- his mother
Jane Alexander & Father
Alexander Maxwell were
at his. house- Took dinner
at Dewitt and May Ann & self
returned to Rochester on
3 P.M. train- & all
took tea with sister
Hannah- brother Aaron too.
Formal letters from
Mrs. Bliss saying I was engaged
for Friday night the 25th
So decided to pack my
trunk & start with D. &
M. A. at 10 A.M. tomorrow
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony went to Batavia and had dinner with Mary McLeans husband. She received a letter from Mrs. Bliss and decided to pack her trunk and leave with D. & M. A. the next day.

entries.fullText:
Left Rochester for
the Michigan Woman
Suffrage campaign-
Dewitt & May Ann in
company as far as
Harrisburg Canada -
When they left to go to
Preston to visit the Perine-
Mary, Billings & Joseph-.
Had a pleasant
ride - after they left &
took out the Graphic &
read T.Ts last statement
it is appalling in its
exposures of their lying &
deceit practiced all round
among them.
Took sleeping car
at Detroit for Grand Rapids
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left Rochester for the Michigan Woman Suffrage campaign. She read T.Ts last statement and took a sleeping car at Detroit for Grand Rapids.

entries.fullText:
Reached Grand Rapids
at 6 A.M. - found Mrs Marion Care Bliss
at her home - Park place
home - she is a most
earnest and energetic
woman - I was not
to lecture this eveing
have to meet with their
Executive Committee
that I was so summarily
commanded hither
Judge Withe their City
President, was present
Mr Hine of Lowell, M &
Mrs Briggs and others - a Mrs
Summer - wife of a merchant
called - beautiful woman -
- it said her husband
actually beats her -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony reaches Grand Rapids and meets with Mrs. Marion Care Bliss and other people. She was not able to lecture that evening and had to meet with the Executive Committee.

entries.fullText:
Spoke in Luce's Hall
large audience - though
a heavy shower just at
7 O'clock - gave my argument-
friends seemed
pleased - some said
there had been no
lecture before that had
made so many notes-
Judge Withe did not
come to introduce me -
so Mrs Bliss herself
walked on to the platform
and officiated - and she did
it in a most dignified
manner
Found Ms Stone
of Kalamazoo at the
rooms on our return-
Mr Geo. Stickney of Grand -
Haver - the state W.S. Sec'y
came from to hear me speak
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony speaks at Luce's Hall in front of a large audience despite a heavy shower. Mrs. Bliss introduces her and Susan meets with Ms. Stone and Mr. Geo. Stickney after the lecture.

entries.fullText: Did not go out to Church -- Mrs Foster-- Editor of the Post-- and Mr Stickney come -- and we mapped out plan of work for me through the campaign to Nov. 3rd.
entries.summaryText: Meeting with Mrs Foster and Mr Stickney to plan campaign work.

entries.fullText: Lowell -- Mich-- Train Hall -- stopped at Mr Jarvis C. Train -- his wife Mrs E.L. Warren Train -- very cordial -- Rev. E.L. Eaton -- Pastor Congregational Church introduced me -- & said my lecture had decided him to vote for woman suffrage -- Mrs. Dr. M.A. Purple -- Lady physician Mr Milton Perry see and Mr Jeffreys John M. Mathewson Pres-- (A unanimous vote for Woman Suffrage). Gone my power of the ballot [AS???]
entries.summaryText: Speaking engagement in Lowell, Michigan with positive reception and unanimous vote for woman suffrage.

entries.fullText: A Mr Jennings here was private in the Old Houses 7st Regiment - Sonia - Nick - Hon. Albert Williams - nominee on prohibition ticket for Att. General - M Clark A. Preston. Pres. W.S.S. was one of Kansas 7th Regiment under brother D R stopped at Bailey House - Mrs Sessions and Ms Preston called- & a ten or more called later when I was trying to take a sleep - but the slamming of the doors & the crossing of plank cross walks, by the waggons [?] out me out of sleep - & so my brain was nothing as free & clear as at Powell - had fine audience- Gave power of Ballot - Ms Dr. came over from Pemamo to get me to speak at their County Fair - but had to refuse -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her travels, people she met, and her speaking engagements. She mentions a Mr. Jennings who was a private in the Old Houses 7th Regiment, Hon. Albert Williams who was a nominee on prohibition ticket for Att. General, and M Clark A. Preston. She also talks about her fine audience and giving a speech on the power of the ballot. Ms Dr. came over from Pemamo to get her to speak at their County Fair but she had to refuse.

entries.fullText: stopped with a Potor - spoke in the M. E. Church - had full house -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony stayed with a person named Potor and spoke at the M. E. Church in Saranac to a full house.

entries.fullText:
Ms Bliss took
me out in carriage
& back after the lecture
good meeting--
entries.summaryText: Ms Bliss took me out in carriage & back after the lecture good meeting--

entries.fullText:
Charles Dole --wife
Mrs Louisa Jameson Dole--
relatives of Reynolds H Roberts
Ms Briggs took
me out 12 miles in
her buggy with two horses
entries.summaryText: Charles Dole --wife Mrs Louisa Jameson Dole-- relatives of Reynolds H Roberts Ms Briggs took me out 12 miles in her buggy with two horses

entries.fullText:
Ball-room-Pasts Hotel
Belmont
J Mason Reynolds - or
Tasmer Reynolds -
King Doris
entries.summaryText: Attended an event at Ball-room-Pasts Hotel in Belmont with J Mason Reynolds, Tasmer Reynolds, and King Doris.

entries.fullText:
Grand Rapids - Buce's Hall
Trade Assembly
Randall or
Trowbridge

Had large audience
and made good
argument -

Mrs Briggs drove
me to her house - 3
miles out of City to dine
- & then went back
home with her after
meeting.
entries.summaryText: Attended a Trade Assembly at Buce's Hall in Grand Rapids with Randall or Trowbridge. Had a large audience and made a good argument. Had dinner with Mrs Briggs at her house 3 miles out of the city after the meeting.

entries.fullText:
Spoke in Universalist
Church at Muskegon.
Major Davis introduced
me. large audience--
stopped at Mr William
McRillips[?] - grandson
of uncle Jimmy McLean-
on Jackson pond &
cousin of brother Aaron--
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spoke at a Universalist Church in Muskegon, introduced by Major Davis to a large audience. She stayed at Mr. William McRillips' place, who is the grandson of uncle Jimmy McLean and cousin of brother Aaron. She also mentioned Jackson pond.

entries.fullText:
Stopped with Mr Charles
Gaylord M. D. --his
wife
beautiful Maine woman
& good friend Mr
Ellsworth -- met Miss
Lelia E. Patridge--
of Philadelphia--teacher--
fine bright lady--who
has been lecturing in the
State--bright, beautiful--
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony stayed with Mr. Charles Gaylord and his wife, along with Mr. Ellsworth. She met Miss Lelia E. Patridge, a teacher from Philadelphia who has been lecturing in the state and described her as a fine, bright, and beautiful lady.

entries.fullText:
Stopped at Pacific Hotel
Lecture in Opera House-
Large audience-
Presiding Elder introduced me
Ms Bruce - Mrs
Morehouse-
Left Muskegon
at 9 a.m. on freight
train, and reached Big Rapids
not till 4 P.M. - tedious -
and had the coldest audience
I have yet had in state
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony stopped at Pacific Hotel in Big Rapids and gave a lecture in Opera House to a large audience. She had a tedious journey from Muskegon and had the coldest audience she has had in the state. Ms Bruce, Mrs Morehouse, and Presiding Elder were mentioned.

entries.fullText:
Music Hall-
George Stickney - Secretary
of State W. . Society introduced me
splendid audience -
Left Grand Haven at
6:30 A.M. - reached
Muskegon at 10 - dined
at Mr McSkelly's - & rode
about town and visited
large steam saw Mills-
wonderful progress on
the old Buttermilk mill
left for Grand Haven
at 3 P.M.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony gave a lecture at Music Hall in Grand Haven to a splendid audience. She visited Mr McSkelly's and rode about town and visited large steam saw Mills. George Stickney and Secretary of State W. . Society were mentioned.

entries.fullText:
went to depot at 8 -
found it slow train and no
connection - so returned
to Mr Stickneys to wait
till 3 P.M. - Mrs. D.
a beautiful young wife
of [?] - with little girl of 4
got telegram of death
of Sisters of 16 at Grand Rapids
and I wrote several letters-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is in Plainwell waiting for a train connection. She meets Mrs. D. who just received a telegram about the death of Sisters of 16 in Grand Rapids and Susan writes several letters.

entries.fullText:
Stopped with Mr Charles
M. Lawler- R.R. man-
his wife Fannie Hulse- of
Orange County- daughter
of Alfred P. Hulse of
Monroe- orange Co- N.J.
An old lady- wife of Mr
William Barnes- farmer of
Rochester- Sons of Temperance-
& school teacher- came to speak
to me- she made chocolate
colored DeLane traveling dress
for me in 1850- or 51- in which
,y last Daguerotype was taken-
- splendid audience- all
noted ayes- for Woman Suffrage-
Edwin G. Alfonse
E.A. Abbott
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is in St Joseph and stays with Mr Charles M. Lawler. She meets an old lady who made a dress for her in 1850 and gives a speech to a splendid audience who are all for Woman Suffrage.

entries.fullText:
"Congregational Church
3:30 P.M. - packed house-
O.S. Willey
Mrs. Henderson
" Colly
Took tea at Mr
Willey's - 15 or 20 called
all earnest good people
- drove back to St.
Jo in pouring rain
and dark"
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends a packed church service in Benton Harbor and has tea with O.S. Willey and other good people before driving back to St. Jo in the rain.

entries.fullText:
"Left St. Joseph Mich at
3:30 and reached Chicago
at 7:45 P.M.-
Found Mrs Jones
as bright & beautiful as
ever - a Tribune lady
reporter - Ms Rogue
was waiting to interview
me- what morbilliy ?
the newspapers do
cater do"
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from St. Joseph to Chicago and is interviewed by a Tribune lady reporter named Ms Rogue.

entries.fullText:
Mrs Jones took me
to artist Mosher's to sit
for pictures - then I
called on Mrs Bradwell
& after that at Aunt A.E.
Dickinsons to Lunch - Uncle
A. come in - he is but a
wreck of his former self- a
perfect fretter and unrecognizable
& unreasonable child - all
the rest well & splendid -
especially cousin Fanny
who is in high school
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits an artist and has lunch with family members in Chicago.

entries.fullText:
Ill. State W.S. A. Mass Meeting
Methodist Church Block - Rev.
Dr. Thomas - the Pastor
spoke - splendid meeting
from 1st session at 11 A.M.
to close at 10.30 P.M.
Mrs De Geer - Mrs Lizzie
Boynton Harbert, Mrs
Forbes - Mr Groner - Phoebe
Couzens & self the speakers
Mrs. J G. Jones Presided
most beautifully - Dear
Aunt Ann Eliza Dickinson
President - so earnest - and
Mrs Barnett -who sent
me $100 check to help me on
my Revolution in 1868-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends a women's suffrage meeting in Chicago and receives a donation for her Revolution publication.

entries.fullText:
Reverend Slade - Pastor
Mrs. Atwell the
sec'y of W. S. A. & entertained
me. First husband nephew of
Grace Greenwood's . Grace's aged
mother -93 lives here with
her son William Clark. Called
on her in bed but serene
& beautiful. All interested in
every question of to-day.
Especially suffrage for women.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Dowagiac Michigan and meets with Reverend Slade and Mrs. Atwell. She also visits Grace Greenwood's aged mother and discusses suffrage for women.

entries.fullText:
[Speak at Elizabeth,
N. Jersey this night
Subject Guilty or Not Guilty]
Postponed to December
Marshall
Opera House
Mr. Morgan Bates, Editor
of the paper and Pres of the W. S. A
Stopped at Mr.
Alexander's - Wife of Quaker
descent Hendricks from
Rochester. The largest
hall & largest audience
of the campaign. And
largest audience ever
assembled for any purpose.
Mrs. Merrill, widow of
Merrill associate editor with
Father Glupman in Rochester years ago.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony speaks at Elizabeth, N. Jersey but it is postponed to December. She then visits Marshall and stays at Mr. Alexander's. She speaks at the Opera House and has the largest audience ever assembled for any purpose. She also meets with Mrs. Merrill, widow of Merrill associate editor with Father Glupman in Rochester years ago.

entries.fullText:
Took 6:30 train to Albion
waited there to 12:40 - wrote
letters & sent two $50 P.O. orders
home to Aaron and Mary.
Stopped
at Winter J. Baxter's, his
beautiful wife and niece of Sully
Holly's, dead - but a
promising daughter Nellie
did the honors handsomely .
Had largest audience
Mr. Baxter introduced me.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to Albion and visits Winter J. Baxter's home. She sends money orders home and attends a large event where she is introduced by Mr. Baxter.

entries.fullText:
At Jonesville,
attended church, Rev.
Childs, congregational
In P.M. had talk
in Congregational Church
with ladies 100 or more
present, resulted in
organizing for work on
election day at polls.
Mrs. Helen
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends church and has a talk with over 100 ladies resulting in organizing work for election day at the polls.

entries.fullText: Mr. O. A. Pritchett introduced me & paid hotel bill. Mrs. E.P. Hamilton wife of the Ed. of Repub. paper. - livest woman Mrs. (Dr.) R. E. Elmo Mrs. Newell Mrs. Frank Raleigh - young woman who came to hotel - bought book - is in favor of W.S. and wants to get poster - her husband & lawyer & paid Attorney of Whiskey ring Had an hour at Train depot went Times office found no notices - no hall engaged , found hall for $30 ordered poster & back to train. A break on road delayed two hours. - reached M. 8 oclock - & rushed to Hotel - cup of tea - & to platform - & spoke one hour and a half.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to Monroe, meets with various people, orders a poster, and speaks for an hour and a half.

entries.fullText: Found Mr. and Mrs. Durton Kent at Depot. The same good people I stopped with 5 years ago. Miss Maggie Thompson, the teacher is now wife of Dan'l Benedict. She introduced me [] asked for collection to pay $80 hall got $20. and forgot to tell me it was lacking - so nothing more was got. Several Gaily contributed a dollar each-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to Adrian, meets with Mr. and Mrs. Durton Kent, and Miss Maggie Thompson, and collects $20 for the hall.

entries.fullText: Stopped Mrs. E.L. Samm Freemen Clough took responsibility of my lecture - "Will Carlton" Michigan Young poet, author of Betsey & I are out, - introduced me very handsomely. - Mrs. J. B. Norris, Mrs. Gallaher, Miss Mead whom I used to see in Leavenworth with Mother Haviland and the Freedmen, lives at Hillsdale. Opera House looked long before 7. So people were going away - it was estimated that 2000 people had to go. the Hillsdale Standard Repub. had announced that the local Com. Mr. Persfield at Head a stationer and the friends of W.S. in .H. did not wish Men to speak at H. But the vast turn out didn't look much that way
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony gave a lecture in Hillsdale, Michigan, which was well-attended despite some opposition from the local committee.

entries.fullText: Mrs. S. M. , M. Gowan, White Pigeon also 70 [?] Senator M. Gowan President of State W.S. Society was ill. Met Giles B. Stebbins at depot. Mr. Frank V. Smith there with Buggy and took Mrs. Samm and self to his house, an elegant one it is too. A great cathedral like a palace, it was built by spiritualists for a church and Mr. Smith obliged to take it and be refitted it up as a dwelling Dr. S. Cutter, brother of Mrs. S, Mrs. J. B. Shipman, Mrs. Celia P. Wooley- secretary Splendid audience again- Here is the state public school and there I found Mrs. Laura S. Haviland who used to be in Leavenworth aiding the colored people in 1865- Here live Mrs. Whitley - a sister of Mrs. Aurelia Judson- Sister Mary's best friend
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony gave a lecture in Coldwater, Michigan, and visited with various acquaintances, including Mrs. Laura S. Haviland and Mrs. Whitley.

entries.fullText: At White Pigeon found audience waiting from 2 P. M. - at which time Henry Collins at advertised me to speak there - involing my taking cars at 1 a midnight - & a breaking up my nights sleep - & I have telegraphed no - and as a consequence hurried at night & lost more sleep than I should to have gone - so slept a half hour from depot - Had another join her at Three Rivers - hundreds going away. Miss Clute introduced me - Driven with Dr E. B. Graham & wife Mary E Hutchison from Prattsburgh N. Y. where I stopped & spoke 20 years ago - her father Lyman Hutchison took me over to Hammandsport-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony speaks at White Pigeon and Three Rivers, despite a difficult journey. She is introduced by Miss Sara A Clute and driven by Dr E. B. Graham and wife Mary E Hutchison from Prattsburgh, NY.

entries.fullText: Levi Sparks a farmer living four miles out arranged my meeting -- Large audience again - & not a single no - scores of women came forward at close of lecture to shake hands & thank me for my truthful words - But not a mortal man or woman, of the City has called me at hotel - only Mr & Mrs Sparks - Dr Bodine - a friend of W. S. - but did not come to speak to me -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony speaks at Miles and is arranged by Levi Sparks. She receives positive feedback from the audience but is not visited by anyone from the city at her hotel.

entries.fullText:
2.20 Geloch G.M ---- It all
Dr. Frank H. Berrick the wife
a niece of Levi Starks - entertained me.
Mr. Starks & wife took me four
miles to B. about noon - lost
my 2 yds nail on way - was
dreadfully fagged out - & instead
of taking dinner - went to bed
for the hour - hair pins, coat
boots & all - & fell asleep - & at
2.20 _ took just a cup of coffee
& went on platform - a fine
audience - spoke mainly on
moral power of ballot for Women
Found Hepsobeth Folger
book - Arnold - daughter of uncle
Aaron & Aunt Loydia Folger - of
Buttonville - Lydia F. Famber - R[?????] [????]
L. C. Fox - L. P. Alexander
Susan B. Strong - Re. W. W.
Wells - Pres. Minister - & Rev. A. P.
Russell M.E. minister -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony speaks on the moral power of ballot for Women in Buchanman and meets several people.

entries.fullText:
Court House - Ms. Phebe D. Allison
her son. C. C. Allison. the Editor of
the National Democrat - & right minded
Stanton B. Thomas
Mrs. John Shaw -
Ms. Eliza Williams Cornell -
daughter of Roderick Williams of Buttonville
called on me - Kenyon Stuart, son
of Phil. & Ruth Stuart lives here -
same story of a perfect
farm - at least & took my stand
on the Judges table - & the people just
packed in standing solid all round it
& inside the her - Such
enthusiam ought - to carry
the state - but alas it has
been aroused out in a very
fine of the township of the
state - the best majority have
and had a single lecture
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony speaks at the Court House in Cassopolis and meets several people.

entries.fullText: Stopped with Mrs Livermore - introduced by Rev. McCarty - Mrs Conable sat on platform - Mrs Lathrop made Finance appeal at beginning & raised $16 - at close I made one & got - $10.50 for Trials Had packed house three time size of Senator Chandlers - It was the Methodist Mrs Lathrop & Gamble shout glory - they said - they hadn't the slightest hope of an audience - but Jackson proved no exception to all my meetings thus far - Mothers cousin Benjamin Reads widow came forward to see me - she with two daughters lives at Napoleon - a few miles from J. her son in law Pryne was with her - A M Brown - whose wife is a Temperance Lecturer - very earnest -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony stopped in Jackson and attended a meeting where Mrs. Lathrop raised $16 and Susan raised $10.50 for Trials. She also met with Benjamin Reads' widow and A M Brown, whose wife is a Temperance Lecturer.

entries.fullText: Opera House - Mrs S. E. Dart - real equinoxial rain all day - Mrs Popineau met on train a step daughter of Mothers Cousin Barney Read of Baldwin's Mill - Hannover Co. Mich. Met Garderers Theatrical Troupe Academy of [?] Halsted at Chicago - Mrs Nelson Renears head woman - & tow beautiful girls Hattie E Roche - the older and Frankie Easton, the youngest & sweetest - lines just round from Aunt A. E. Dickinson - The report Olive Logan's return to the Stage a failure - she was false to it when she left it - and false to woman suffrage & best worker when she returned it -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attended a performance at the Opera House in Lansing and received news from Aunt A. E. Dickinson. She also heard reports of Olive Logan's return to the stage being a failure.

people: C. V. De Bund - Bancroft St.
entries.fullText:
East Saginaw
Academy of music
S.S. Carrigues
C. V. De Bund - Bancroft St.
Miss Johnson
entries.summaryText: Attended an event at the Academy of music in East Saginaw with S.S. Carrigues, C. V. De Bund - Bancroft St., and Miss Johnson.

geographicalLocations: 459 Second st - west side of Cass Park
entries.fullText:
[East Saginaw] Detroit
Young Men's Hall
Giles B. Stebbins - 459
Second st - west side of Cass Park
entries.summaryText: Attended an event at Young Men's Hall in Detroit with Giles B. Stebbins.

entries.fullText: Stopped at Duncan Stewarts - his wife, Frank McQuigg - is cousin of Eliz. & Julia Brown -- Had splendid audience & made one of my best speeches Mr Littlefield of Oswego N. Y. - an old abolitionist came to me at close & went to Mr Stewarts & stopped until car time - 1 A.M. - then I took sleeping car for Detroit -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony stopped at Duncan Stewarts and made a speech to a splendid audience. She met with Mr. Littlefield and took a sleeping car to Detroit.

entries.fullText: arrived at 7.30 - found cousins Samantha & Henry Lapham at Mr Ladds - Cousin Carrie Vails new home - had a very pleasant day - took a good sleep in P.M. - - Giles B. & Catherine Stebbins called in evening
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived in Detroit and spent a pleasant day with her cousins and visited Cousin Carrie Vails' new home. Giles B. & Catherine Stebbins called in the evening.

entries.fullText: - immense audience
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony speaks to an immense audience at Hodges Hotel in Pontiac on November 2, 1874.

entries.fullText: - found Mrs Stebbins, Boothe, Gardner & other women working at the polls - Dined at Mrs [I Smiths?] - the Stebbins - Spent P.M. at Cousin Benjamin Anthony's -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony observes women working at the polls on Election Day in Detroit on November 3, 1874. She dines with Mrs. [I Smiths?] and spends the afternoon at Cousin Benjamin Anthony's.

entries.fullText:
From Detroit to
Rochester-
Took Cars at
6.10 - and [?]
home at 10:25 pm
The newspaper returns
show woman Suffrage
lost - 3 or 5 to 1 -
what better could be
expected every whiskey
maker, [?] drinker,
every gambler every Libertine
every ignorant besotted man
against us - & then the other
extreme - every narrow
selfish religious bigot -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Detroit to Rochester and reflects on the recent loss of the woman suffrage movement.
Susan B. Anthony is at home.

entries.fullText:
Called on
niece Maggie -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony called on her niece Maggie.

entries.fullText:
Beautiful day -
mother & Mary -
& the two school
teachers Merriam
& Baker rode out
to Mt Hope - Mr
Knowles took them
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spent a beautiful day at home with her mother and Mary. Later, Merriam and Baker, two school teachers, rode out to Mt Hope with Mr. Knowles.

entries.fullText:
At Home
Sister Hannah & self went
to Unitarian Church - & thence
to Mt Hope- - a beautiful;
soft day- the first time
Sister H. had been there to
visit dear Sister Gula's grave
-a whole year - this day of
the week since she passed
on to the Shining Shore - as
we rested there we wondered
if her spirits eye saw us -
what a swift passing year & yet
none like an age -

I went thence to niece
Maggie's & dined, brother Aaron
had arrived with little Mary
[?] returned with me - then
Sister H. & self went to Plym
Church at eve'g with A. and
how her spirit did hover
over us - I could see & hear
& feel her - These anniversary
days bring her so keenly to us
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits the Unitarian Church and Mt Hope to visit Sister Gula's grave. She then visits her niece Maggie and attends Plym Church in the evening with A. to remember Sister Gula.

entries.fullText:
At Home
Had Mrs Segar to
[?sew]- making over in
part my American silk
worn almost steady for
two years - It is a
marvel for durability-
This is the day
of the month, dear, Sister
Gulhma died - just one
year ago - the void
seems even greater
with this lapse of
time - looking &
working -but no return
Heaven help us our
[? ?] to leave as
priority a record
[? in?] us - Brother A
spent eve with Sister H.
and talked & [?] over his bereavements
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony has Mrs. Segar over to sew and remembers Sister Gulhma who passed away a year ago. Brother A spends the evening with Sister H. and talks about his bereavements.

entries.fullText:
Niece Maggie &
husband Geo L. Baker
dined with us - &
after dinner Aaron
asked them up to
his room & there
showed them all of
sister Gula's little
treasures - & talked
over her life & death
entries.summaryText: Niece Maggie & husband Geo L. Baker dine with Susan B. Anthony and Aaron shows them sister Gula's little treasures and they talk about her life and death.

entries.fullText:
Mrs Segan still here
One year ago to night
sister Mary Sutton
& her Fannie - & brother
D. A. & sister Annie
[?] little Dan & little
Susan A. came - The
snow was falling &
the weather dreary
and this day is just
very cold -
Sister Hannah &
self went to the S. C. [?]
[?] [?] word friends
[?] Pow Willis &
on next stop of work
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about the people present one year ago on this night and the weather being very cold. She also mentions Sister Hannah and going to the S.C. [?] and Pow Willis on the next stop of work.

entries.fullText:
One year ago this
day at 2. P.M. we
laid on dear Gula's
poor body in Mt Hope
with her Thomas Reinz,
Anne Eliza & Father - [?]
more there, one less here -
& soon we must - say
still and then more there-
our then less, head -
Min Baker & Merriam had annuals
They were going to Hattie Baker nieces
to tea- after dinner was more - brother
A. Said to them he would go down there
after & accompany them home- as they may []-
It shot through all our hearts- Poor Matthias
said- & don't know what do think of Aaron
- His new 3/4 bedstand come this P.M.- [????]
I was helping him make changes- I told him how
we felt & hoped he would not be caught in the
[lett] set for family - he laughed at me-
said he only wanted to make it pleasant on
the girls why they boarded with us.
At Home-
Went down town- bought
silk wrappers- $18- seems
the merriest extravagance- still
cannot wear Merina- called
at Democrat officer- Mrs Griffings
and other places-
Then P. M. , swept and put in
order brother Aaron's
room- It is very
cozy and comfortable- and
it does seem as if
he must enjoy himself
just as well as it is possible
for him to do without the
wife of his youth-- but no
one else could possibly add
anything that he only a load
to carry-- he went to niece
Maggie's & staid all night
George had to stay in Depot
all night -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about the anniversary of Gula's death, family gatherings, and her brother Aaron's new bedstand.

entries.fullText:
Took 10.40 P.M. train
for Albany -
Helped sister Mary sweep
the parlors & set the house -
order before leaving - sister
Mary, & the two boarder teachers
Ellen S. Baker & Hattie Merriam
went to niece Maggies to tea -
I spent the P.M. in packing
trunk & picking up to leave -
had a fire in my little store
in my bedroom - "office" Aaron
calls it for the first time - &
it did seem so cozy & nice - to
feel that & had a room of my own
-- Aaron didn't go to accompany
the teachers home - though the city
was more perilous than that of Thursday night
- Sister Hannah came over & spent eve'g
the girls came home & both took seats in
parlor with us - sister H. left & they
stuck by - brother went to depot with
me - the first time since dear Gulas
death -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to Albany, spends time with family and friends, and reflects on her personal life.

entries.fullText:
Albany -
Reached depot at 7 A. M.
Breakfasted at Phebe Jones
and the went to Lydia Motts
found her feeble but still
bright & awake to every
thing pertaining to progress -
- She may now last through
the winter to spring - if
nothing new sets in & she gets no cold -
Phebe Jones came up & sat
with us before dinner & between
dinner & tea & after tea -
had a very pleasant visit
and Lydia seemed to
enjoy it as much -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Lydia Motts and Phebe Jones in Albany and reflects on their health and their shared interest in progress.

entries.fullText:
Lecture in Universalist Church -
Pastor Rev. Oren Perkins -
wife Mrs Sarah M. C. Perkins -
Left Lydia Motts at 7.30 - she still
in bed coughing & raising - & looking
very very feeble & still seemed so bright-
- had great room for trunk. went
first down to Susquehannah Depot
& learned there they had new Depot
up at Centraal R.R.- & then fairly
ran back there- no R.R. man
gives travelers any information
of changes-- just barely saved
the train- wrote letters on Car
drawing room- to Mother & one to
cousins Geo. & E. Caldwell inviting
them to spend Dec. 2nd- Our mothers
81st birth day with us- Dined
with the Caprons at Oneonta & then
stage to Morriss- 16 miles- took a
sleep- & then found a small audience
less then 100- bit good- great contrast
to my Michigan audiences-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony lectures in Universalist Church in Morris, Otsego Co. and writes about her travels, including a visit to Susquehannah Depot and a dinner with the Caprons at Oneonta.

entries.fullText:
M.E. Church-
stopped at Rev
Southworths- the Pastor
Hon. Wm. C. Fields- former M.C. introduced me
Mr Loveland- Mr. Gile
drove over from Morris
with Mrs Perkins- Livery
horse & buggy- quite misty
& rainy all day- & at
evening a hard rain- still
nearly 100 people present.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony speaks at M.E. Church in Laurens, Otsego Co. and meets with various people, including Rev Southworths and Hon. Wm. C. Fields.

entries.fullText:
New Berlin -
Hall
Stopped of Mr Russell
Leonards - Cotton manu
facturer - used to go to
school with me at old
academy at South Adams -
- Mr Parsons teacher -
his father's name Jesse
Had good audience
- Mrs May Aylesworth
Fuller - formely of 6 th
street Rochester spoke with me
Stage from Morris to
New Berlin - 4 to 6 P.M. - &
drove back from Laurens to
Morris in forenoon -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits New Berlin, meets with Mr. Russell and Leonards, and has a good audience.

entries.fullText:
Sherburne-
M. E. Church
Stopped with the
Pastor Hubbard Fox -
James P. Knowles of
Smyrna- Chenago Co - 4 miles
and Mrs Chasidy Myres -
from Columbus -5 miles -
Had good audience
and beautiful moonlight
evening - took stage from
New Berlin to train at 5 A. M.
cold & dark start -
no letters here -
met here the Mrs Rexfords
& Mrs Lathrop - aunts of the
Rev. D. K. Bartlolls wife -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Sherburne, stays with Pastor Hubbard Fox, meets James P. Knowles and Mrs. Chasidy Myres, and has a good audience.

entries.fullText:
Took Cars at 10.45 - from Sherburne
Lottie M. Burrows - Teacher
Mrs Geo. Sam'l Perlee -
John Swan Randall (Spiritualist)
Elmore Sharpe.
The ground white with
snow & continued snowing
until near night - an
audience 150 or more - Dr.
H. H. Beecher - member of [legislature ?]
from this district, last year -
introduced me - made
pretty fair speech - the
Rev. Mr Scovel not present -
- nor Martin McLean -
(Mrs Elizabeth Stanton very
friendly - also Mrs.Summe
Mr Robert A. Stanton)
A last called on Martin McLean - he
intended to call - but had too much
company & work - -
W. S. Hewitt - Pres. Lecture Com. -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony gave a lecture in Norwich, with an audience of 150 or more. She was introduced by Dr. H. H. Beecher and called on Martin McLean, who was too busy to attend.

entries.fullText:
At James Hotel - Concord Hall -
Small meeting - no
local interest - not a
woman called on me -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony gave a lecture in Oxford, but there was little local interest and no women attended.

entries.fullText:
Free Will Baptist Church
Rev. Mr Waldron - Pastor
Stopped Eagle Hotel -
Drove over from oxford
in Butler - first sleigh ride
of the season - very nice & pleasant
Had crowded house -
many unable to get seats & many
could not get inside the house -
spoke 1 1/2 hours on Temperance
& woman's need of the ballot
to make her an efficient and
in the Temperance movement -
- Dr. H.H.. Beecher escorted
me over to the church - the
pastors wife was very cordial
& earnest. A woman came
to me & said she was present
at my meeting in Norwich - 20
years ago -when I spoke in 54 of
the County seats of the state -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony speaks on Temperance and woman's need of the ballot in Norwich, has a sleigh ride in Butler, and meets with Dr. H.H. Beecher and a woman who attended her meeting 20 years ago.

entries.fullText:
good Templars Hall
Chenango Hotel - Rainy
day - small audience -
spoke on Temperance
not a letter nor
a list from home since
& left
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony speaks on Temperance to a small audience in Greene and notes the lack of communication from home.

entries.fullText:
Free conference Hall-
Dr T.B. Brown- owner
Bright and beautiful day.
Reached B at 1 P.M.
Henry Vilkerson
husband of Cousin Harriet
Richardson- daughter of Brother's Cousin Ira. R.-
met me at Depot-
They home beautiful home
& two children Arthur &
Annie- 8 years between them
had about 100 people
in that little unpopular
Hall of Dr Browns- in
by place- I made tolerable
speech- could not ride
out of my chagrin at Mrs
Perkins for taking me to a
2nd-a [?] class hall in B.
David B Crowin called after lecture.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony speaks at a conference hall in Binghampton and is disappointed with the venue. She visits Cousin Harriet Richardson and learns about her nephew's alcoholism.

entries.fullText:
Spent the day at Cousin
Harriet Richardson's- had
good visit her sister Aman
da's son Charlie has become
a confirmed drunkard- a
dreadful sorrow to them all-
particulary to his Grand mother
& Aunt Esther Richardson with homes he lives-
no letter her at
Bignhampton from home-
not a [?[ since I left
So Telegraphed Mrs R. B.
Gleason at Elmira water to cure that I could
not visit them to visit as I had intended- & take
the 4:45 P.M.- reached home
at 11:20- took back and found all as w
& next A.M. all very well-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Cousin Harriet Richardson and learns about her nephew's alcoholism. She telegraphs Mrs. R. B. Gleason at Elmira to let her know she cannot visit and returns home.

entries.fullText: Attended 1st Presbyterian Church and heard Rev. Asa R. Fiske preach - on Duty of the State to educate all her children - it was a genuinely Democratic [ underscored ] assertion - for women & for the poor of the state - to the suffrage & the highest education niece Maggie & brother Aaron heard it- and make niece Maggie & her boys - Husband George & sons Harry & J. R dined with us - it was a pleasant day & a profitable one to me, too - so for as Mr Fisk's sermon it was worthy Geo. Wm. Curtis in it's Rhetoric Huldah Anthony & Marie called in evening - found no letter from [Redpather ?] & which augurs no lecture engagements for me -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attended church and heard a sermon about the duty of the state to educate all children. She spent a pleasant day with family and friends and received no lecture engagements.

entries.fullText: Sister H & self went down town - to look for bonnets for winter -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony went shopping for winter bonnets with her sister.

entries.fullText:
Sister Mary went down
town & found steel grey
silk to put flower on
my Anna Dickinson grey
silk-that she gave me
my 50th birthday-5 years
ago next February-
entries.summaryText: Sister Mary found steel grey silk to put a flower on Susan's Anna Dickinson grey silk.

entries.fullText:
Heavy snow on
the ground-
Wrote all day-letters,
to every body about getting
Congress to submit
something for Woman
Suffrage this very
session-
Mother came up into my
room in P.M -and she & I went in
and sat a while with Aaron - then he
went over to see niece Maggie & her
darling boys- - I didn't go out
-A took Miss Merrim to
Westminster Church - Mr
Hawley spent evening with
Miss Baker
entries.summaryText: Susan wrote letters all day about getting Congress to submit something for Woman Suffrage. She spent time with her mother and Aaron. Miss Merrim was taken to Westminster Church and Mr. Hawley spent the evening with Miss Baker.

entries.fullText:
DECEMBER TUESDAY, 1 1874
Four years ago
tonight I returned
from the west to find
Gula's Thomas King
very ill with Typhoid
- rheumatic fever - and
his death on the 4th
proved the fatal blow
to her - she never seemed
able to rally wholly from
the shock - how striffed
she was - her first born-
the noble from Ann Eliza - her
youngest born T. H. - only
her Maggie & her husband
left - & she so soon
followed them over the
dark river - into we hope
the bright land - when more
is known, felt of love and loving
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about the death of Gula's Thomas King from Typhoid fever.

entries.fullText:
Four years ago
tonight I returned
from the west to find
Gula's Thomas King
very ill with Typhoid
- rheumatic fever - and
his death on the 4th
proved the fatal blow
to her - she never seemed
able to rally wholly from
the shock - how striffed
she was - her first born-
the noble from Ann Eliza - her
youngest born T. H. - only
her Maggie & her husband
left - & she so soon
followed them over the
dark river - into we hope
the bright land - when more
is known, felt of love and loving
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony reflects on the death of Gula's Thomas King from Typhoid fever.

entries.fullText:
My Mother's 81st
Birth Day - The second
one that we have had
no dear Gula to enjoy
with us in the body - for
ten years previous to the last
year another has seen her four
daughters around her table on
her returning birth day anniversary

Dined at 5 P. M. Sister Hunt
& Frank, Wendell & Louise - niece
Maggie & her Hary & Tommy King
gathered around the table - a
telegram come from brother Bob,
-Greetings & love from all to our mother
on her 81st Birth day" - Sent reply
in Mothers name - "Telegram
received - Rochester children & grandchildren
dined here. Kansas children remembered
Mary all my children rejoice in theirs
as does their mother in hers L.R.A.
I selected Mrs Herman's "Image in the
Heart" to read - but was too hoarse &
feared I should not be able to keep calm
Brother A carried T. H. home - King staid
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her mother's 81st birthday celebration, including a telegram from her brother Bob and a dinner with family members in Rochester.

entries.fullText:
Went to Rent's
Sat for pictures again -
I want to get a satisfactory
one - got letter from
Mrs Stanton - also,
one from E. M. Davis

Throat & brochicals
filled up - & very hoarser
Do not like these
repeated colds and
throat & head difficulties
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony goes to Rent's for pictures and receives letters from Mrs. Stanton and E. M. Davis, but is feeling ill with throat and head difficulties.

entries.fullText: 4th Anniversary of the death of sister Guelma's darling Thomas King McLean - How like a night-mare dream the interim seems - Sister Gula's decline & long, suffering prostration and death - one year ago - and this year since her death one of untold & unexpected anxiety that weighs me down - God grant it is without cause save in my own fancy - I cannot bear to see the high ideal broken - and stoopings to little weaknesses belonging only to small natures -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about the 4th anniversary of the death of sister Guelma's darling Thomas King McLean and the anxiety she feels since her death.

entries.fullText:
At home
worked on letters &
papers of this & last year
all day - putting them
up & packing away -
Snowy morn'g -
At even'g I went
over to call on Maggie
- It has been a
sad day for me -
every way seems
hedged up -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends the day at home working on letters and papers. She visits Maggie in the evening and expresses feeling sad and trapped.

entries.fullText:
After tea asked
brother, to go with
me to see, the painting
"The Prodigal Son"
which, after some hesitation
- & friendly joking
on drawing cuts as to
who should pay - he accepted
- had a wonderful picture
it is - -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony goes to see the painting "The Prodigal Son" with her brother and enjoys it.

entries.fullText:
Left home for
Washington at 5 P. M -
niece Maggie came
to dinner - also George
& little King - Geo
drove Mary home
on his sleigh - & Maggie
went down town with me
& got bonnet at Backus -
gloves - my last [?]
of the Bo a velvet - & [?]
[?] -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left home for Washington and had dinner with her niece Maggie, George, and little King. She also went shopping with Maggie and got a bonnet and gloves.

entries.fullText:
Arrived Washington
Mrs. Sargent & all
the friends said
we meet hold
our usual Con
Mrs Stanton
& others felt -
we shouldn't
try to hold the
Con - that the
Beecher scandal
has made it
unwise for
us to attempt
it
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived in Washington and was told by Mrs. Sargent and friends that they should hold their usual convention. However, Mrs. Stanton and others felt that they shouldn't try to hold the convention due to the Beecher scandal making it unwise to attempt it.

entries.fullText: DECEMBER THURSDAY, 10 1874.

Returned to
Philadelphia &
E. M. Davis said
go ahead &
ditto L. Mott
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony returned to Philadelphia and received encouragement from E. M. Davis and L. Mott.

entries.fullText: Spent A. M. at Mrs Thompsons - after dinner went to M. Davis office - 333 Walnut St -- and then with him to Roadside to visit Lucretia Mott
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Mrs. Thompson in the morning, goes to M. Davis' office and then visits Lucretia Mott at Roadside.

entries.fullText: At Roadside - Penn - Lucretia Motts - she is very feeble- still very bright & interested in all things of to day - she will be 82 years old the 5th of Jan. 1875 - making her 11 months older than my mother - born Jan 5th 1793 - Had very pleasant visit - in P. M. Maria Davis & son Willie drove me over to Germantown -Sarah Pugh - Mrs Fannie Ames there to tea - went to Rev. G. S. Ames - - [?] & staid all night-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Lucretia Mott at Roadside and then goes to Germantown to have tea with Sarah Pugh and Mrs. Fannie Ames before staying the night at Rev. G. S. Ames' place.

entries.fullText:
Sarah Pugh went into
Philadelphia with me -
called Sarah M. Blintocks store -
Dined with me at Misses
Thompsons - there I called
E. M. Davis office - & there
to D. J. Kilgores - & there
to John & Sarah Hurne
and heard the Katie
King fraud from them
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony went to Philadelphia with Sarah Pugh and visited several places including Sarah M. Blintocks store, Misses Thompsons, E. M. Davis office, D. J. Kilgores, and John & Sarah Hurne. She also heard about the Katie King fraud.

entries.fullText:
From Philadelphia to
New York - at 11 A.M.
Anna Thomson - very
feeble - in company, to
Jersey City - Preached
Tenafly at 4 P.M. - &
found a warm welcome
So much to get
out Call for Jan
Con. at Washington
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony traveled from Philadelphia to New York with Anna Thomson. She preached at Tenafly and received a warm welcome. She also mentioned a call for Jan Con. at Washington.

entries.fullText:
wrote letters for
Washington National
Convention -
got off 30 or 40
Rode to
Englewood with
Bob - he is still
home - but he has
to gain use of
his leg -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about writing letters for the Washington National Convention, riding to Englewood with Bob, and his leg.

entries.fullText:
Had warm reception
by Mrs Lozier this A.M.
she told me prospect that her
Woman's Medical College
to which she had given
13 years hard work - and
$16.000 dollars seemed
about to be "gobbled" up
by the men (underscored ) doctors - to
go out of control of
women altogether -
Took 10.30 train for
Albany - arrived at
2.30 P.M. - found
my dear friend Lydia
very bright - but very weak
- Phebe Jonese spent the
evening with us -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about Mrs. Lozier's Woman's Medical College being taken over by male doctors and her visit to Albany to see her friend Lydia and spending the evening with Phebe Jonese.

entries.fullText:
At Albany -
Lydia Motts -
103 Colmbia St.
Snow falling
Phebe Jones here most
of the day -
Mary Taff
daughter of William
Taff - dined here -
At 8 Lydia went
to bed & I down to
dining room to scribble
letters -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is in Albany visiting Lydia Motts and Phebe Jones. Mary Taff, daughter of William Taff, dined with them. Lydia went to bed early while Susan stayed up to write letters.

entries.fullText:
From Albany
To Greenwich Wash.Co. N.Y.
Phebe H. Jones went to
Saratoga Depot with me at 12 am
- at Troy called at Clarks
Boarding House - then at Dr
LeRoy McLean's Office - then on
to E.K.G. Clarks - 8 Washington St -
- Letter from Mrs A.C. Holmes - no
Lecture at Greenwich on Tuesday
week crowded full for Christmas -
LeRoy seemed very genial on the
subject of his recent marriage, Nov 21st
- did not call on his wife - took
dinner at Clarks - 2 Cars at 5
P.M. - - Found De Witt McLean at
his house - the first time I ever
called at his house since his marriage
- Julia Holmes - his wife Mary's sister
was there - took at Hotel with [?]
- he called with me on Mrs. A.C. Holmes
slept at Dr Witts - It seems a
forlorn way to live - taking meals
at hotel & only sleeping in the great house
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Albany to Greenwich, stopping at various locations along the way. She receives a letter from Mrs. A.C. Holmes and learns that there will be no lecture in Greenwich on Tuesday. She visits De Witt McLean's house for the first time since his marriage and comments on the forlorn way he and his wife are living.

entries.fullText:
called at Mrs Holmes -
Helen Whipple Pettis - &
Ida Whipple Grimes -
Dined at Mrs Holmes - then
with her visited the Main
School - talked to scholars
- called on Mrs Stone Mullins
- used to be Magg. White - then
to see Mrs Holmes - and to
Sunday School Festival at the
little new Dutch Reform Church -
- saw for first time Mrs Holmes
sister Mary E. [Mory?] Masters
- beautiful genial woman -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Greenwich, calls on Mrs. Holmes and visits the Main School, Sunday School Festival at the Dutch Reform Church, and meets Mrs. Holmes' sister Mary E. [Mory?] Masters.

entries.fullText:
From Greenwich to
Battenville - at 11 A.M.
Dined Elijah Hyatts -
both he a wife Candace
seemed very glad to see me -
- got Reg & I went all through
my father's brick house - which
was our home from /32 to /38 -
- many changes - but still the
old familiar place -
There back to Abigail Fitch
McLeans - took two hours
sleep & then cup of tea - & to
lecture - Fitch & Cornelia with
me - little M.C. church packed-
& many old faces there - but all so
very much changed I hardly
could recognize which was which -
Slept at McLeans - in what
used to be John C's Parlor
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Battenville, dines with Elijah Hyatts, visits her childhood home, and attends a lecture at the M.C. church with Fitch and Cornelia.

entries.fullText:
From Battenville - in A.M.
Elizabeth took horse & buggy
& carried Candace & me out
to the burial ground - & there
I read the stones of little
Eliza - little Anthony -
Grand Father & Grand Mother
Read - & my others - but
it was too cold to stay
long - the cold & snow
to severe - caled on June
McLean- drove up to
the Old Bassett place to see
Matthew Burdich - who is
73 & totally blind - he
too remembered the older
times, when made their
beautiful flour for all
the farmers in vicinity -
Dined at Eliza & Sally Ann Hyatts
Fitch took me to Center Falls -
had good meeting there.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits a burial ground in Battenville and meets with June McLean and Matthew Burdich. She also dines with Eliza and Sally Ann Hyatts and attends a meeting in Center Falls.

entries.fullText:
Good meeting at Centre
Falls - last night -
Mrs Dailey very feeble;
not much of the old
spirit left -
Emeline Dailey White
married to Andrew
Hutton - worth $40,000 -
Monroe Connelly carried
me down to Greenwich
at noon - called on
Mr & Mrs Wilson -
Dewitt McLean & self
Dined with Mrs A.C. Holmes
- & her daughter Mrs Mattie
Holmes Mendell - Mr U.
called with me at Dr Hiram
Corliss for an hour - he too was
very glad to see me - & then
had pleasant chat with
Mrs H. to bed time
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends a meeting in Center Falls and visits Greenwich, where she dines with Mrs A.C. Holmes and her daughter and meets with Dr Hiram Corliss and Mrs H.

entries.fullText:
From Greenwich
to West Cambridge
to speak in the old
Whiteside - meeting house
Ms A. G. Holmes went
with me - at 5 P.M -
took tea at [?] - Ms B.
Staid all night- I rode
over to David Bakers - 5 miles
after the lecture -
Had large audience that
full house - 150 people - &
made pretty good speech -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony speaks at the Whiteside meeting house in West Cambridge to a large audience of 150 people.

entries.fullText:
At Easton -
Friends Seminary Hall -
David Baker -
Beautiful, bright day -
Package letter here from
Mrs Stanton - but no word
from her son - Mr E. Smith
Miller's reply to Mrs Stanton's
appeal for help to pay
Washington convention expenses
mere says "Poor Pete" - & no
note from Gerrit Smith -
- no letter from home either
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony receives a package letter from Mrs Stanton but no word from her son or Gerrit Smith.

entries.fullText: From Easton to Hoosier Falls called at Chloe Peckham Dissons - her father & mother Joseph W. & Elizabeth - Lydia G - Betty & husband Sylvanus - Hiram Gifford & wife Lois Hull & May Peckham Davis - & Emily Peckham all them to visit - how good & old time their faces did look - but I had to take hasty lunch & leave from the Valley Depot - met Dr. R. R. McLean at Eagle Ridge & little Sarah & Ed -- all very nice? at Dr.'s home - took a sleep - them at 7 a cup of tea - & at 7:30 found a large audience at the Hall -- Mrs. Holmes staid all day Sunday at Kenyons - came to [?] on A. M. train - & was too ill to go out to lecture
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Easton to Hoosier Falls, visiting Chloe Peckham Dissons and other acquaintances. She meets Dr. R. R. McLean and little Sarah & Ed. She lectures at the Hall and Mrs. Holmes is too ill to attend.

entries.fullText: At Hoosier Falls - Dr. Henry McLean's - Mrs. Sarah Gray the artist - call - Rev. Mr. Tatlock the Presbyterian Pastor called - in P. M. rode out with Doctor & called on Mrs Steven - & Mrs Holmes at Mrs Gray's - Mrs H. had severe attack of dyspepsia - Dr & wife took tea with me at Sarah McLean Moulton's - Oscar Moulton - Poor Sarah still mourns the loss of her Mother & still keenly feels the loss of her Father - now so wholly absorbed with his new wife & baby - Dr. & wive took tea with me at Sarah McLean Moulton's- Oscar Moulton- Poor Sarah still mourns the loss of her mother & still keenly feels the loss of her Father- no so wholly absortion with his new wife & baby-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Dr. Henry McLean's and meets Mrs. Sarah Gray and Rev. Mr. Tatlock. She also visits Mrs. Steven and Mrs. Holmes, who is ill. She has tea with Dr. & wife and Oscar Moulton at Sarah McLean Moulton's.

entries.fullText:
To North Adams
at 9.15 - - Arnalus Hall -
Cousin Hattie Cook Cady's
husband Tory Cady -
Had good nap in P.M.
- small audience - very
cold night - The M.E.
minister introduced me -
the Congregational Baptist
members present & the universalist
staid home to take care of the
baby that his wife might see
& hear me - all of them
seemed very much pleased
with my speech
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to North Adams and gives a speech to a small audience.

entries.fullText:
To South Adams - at 12.30
stopped Uncle Abram Anthony's
Aunt Eunice feeble & almost white
haired - Uncle Smart - youngest
son Albert at home & daughter
Susan & two children -
Charles Bowen - son of
Uncle Sam Bowen called -
Hattie Cook Cady took me
to her husbands shoe factory -
- make 600 pair a day & employ
80 men & women - then to
Sampson's factory to see the
China - men work -then
to Oliver & Harvey Arnolds
Print Factory - & the methods
are truly wonderful -
Large audience & most
attentive listening - good collection
This day makes brother
A.M. McLean 62 years old
only 8 years to Fathers age -
Uncle Abram Anthony is 68 - one year gone
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits family members and factories in South Adams and gives a speech to a large and attentive audience.

entries.fullText:
Mrs George Peasly
Marble Cutter - Minorra - Minn

Alta M Hulett
131 & 133 - La Saille St - Chicago

Mrs M. Graham - Cincinnatti
Temperance Lecturer
entries.summaryText: Mrs George Peasly, Alta M Hulett, and Mrs M. Graham's information.

entries.fullText:
John F Hinda
Webster - Mass -
wants lecture next season

Ann Arbor - Mich.
Charlotte Morris} Decatur
Mrs B. Hathaway} for Buren Co. Mich
Mrs P. L. Thomas } Schooleraft
Mrs. E. L. Brown} Kaleamazoo Co.
Mrs L. M. McGowan - White Pigeon - Mich

Mrs R. L. Taney - Lawrence - Kan -
or [?]

Mrs G. W. Houner
Oskaloosa - Iowa

Georgia E Harrington
Paducah - McCracken Co. Ky.

Carlton Peck } Lapeer
John Matteson } Lapeer co. Mich
entries.summaryText: Various people and locations mentioned.

entries.fullText:
Wm. Harris. Wants me
to lecture for Good Templars
in Rochester in Febry
entries.summaryText: Wm. Harris wants Susan B. Anthony to lecture for Good Templars in Rochester in February.

entries.fullText:
Bot back 299.99 99.85
27 Jackson 28.50 39
24 Lansing 23.80 26

entries.fullText:
Date Received Paid
Spent for
Sundries during
the month 9.10
24 Rochester to Grand

entries.fullText:
At Tenafly
Wrote again all
day - both Mrs
S & self -
And had
a long, long talk
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spent the day writing and talking with Mrs. S in Tenafly.

entries.fullText: Left Tenafly at 12 noon - for New York - Bunched at Mrs Phelps - she not in - then downtown to Associated Press Office - found that the N.J. papers had rejected Washington despatch of part of our January Convention - no doubt to punish us all for Mrs Stantons interference in the Beecher Tilton scandal against Beecher - The whole N. Y. Press seems subsidized to him - Dined with Mr Phelps - Mrs Blake & Winchester met me there - talked up the Wash. Con. & then slept at Mrs. Lozier's no house - in New York
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to New York from Tenafly and discusses the rejection of a Washington dispatch by N.J. papers regarding the January Convention. She dines with Mr. Phelps and meets with Mrs. Blake and Winchester to discuss the Washington Convention before sleeping at Mrs. Lozier's.

entries.fullText:
Jan 1st, 1874

The new year opens with bright sunshine and a clear sky. May it be to me a year of earnest work for the cause of human rights. I feel that I have not done what I ought to have done the past year. I have not been as faithful to my work as I should have been. I have not been as true to myself as I should have been. I have not been as true to my friends as I should have been. I have not been as true to my country as I should have been. I have not been as true to my God as I should have been. May the new year find me a better woman than the old.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony reflects on the past year and sets goals for the new year.
